The bear was identified via DNA from a previous research project, but was not captured or killed because its behavior was a natural response to a surprise encounter involving physical contact.Board of Review Report: The Death of Mr. Brad Treat due to a grizzly bear attack, June 29, 2016 on the Flathead National Forest. http://igbconline.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/160629_BOR_Report_Treat_NCDE.pdf |- |Lance Crosby, 63, male ||{{dts|August 7, 2015}}|| Wild || [[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]]||Crosby, an employee at a medical clinic in the park, was reported missing when he did not report for work. A park ranger found his body in a popular off-trail area less than a mile (1 600 m) from Elephant Back Loop Trail, an area he was known to frequent. His body was partially consumed and covered. Puncture wounds on his arms indicated he had tried to defend himself. Based on the presence of a sow grizzly and a cub in the area, the sow was deemed responsible for the attack. The sow was captured and killed after it was found to be the bear that killed Crosby.{{cite web|title=Bear might be put down after hiker is killed|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/08/us/yellowstone-grizzly-bear-attack-hiker-dead-feat/index.html|publisher=CNN News|accessdate=August 10, 2015}}{{cite web|title=Yellowstone grizzly put down after hiker killed|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/08/13/us/yellowstone-grizzly-bear-put-down-hiker-attack-feat/index.html|publisher=CNN News|accessdate=August 13, 2015}} There were public appeals to not kill the sow, but the park superintendent decided there was a risk the sow might kill again; based on July 6, 2011 and August 24, 2011 killings in the park, where another sow was present at both those killings.{{Cite web|title = What Do You Do With a Bear That Kills a Person?|url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/08/150820-grizzly-yellowstone-maul-wenk-blaze/|website = National Geographic News|accessdate = 2015-08-21|first = Todd|last = Wilkinson|first2 = National Geographic PUBLISHED August|last2 = 20}} |- |Ken Novotny, 53, male ||{{dts|September 17, 2014}}|| Wild || near [[Norman Wells, Northwest Territories]]||While on a hunting trip near Norman Wells, Novotny was charged and struck by a bear. Friends reported Novotny had just killed a moose and was prepping his prize when the bear "came out of nowhere." He died on the scene. Authorities later found and killed the bear responsible for his death.{{cite web|title=Tragedy Strikes Family Twice|url=http://www.wctrib.com/content/tragedy-strikes-family-twice|work=[[West Central Tribune]]|last=Cherveny|first=Tom|accessdate=24 September 2014|date=22 September 2014}} |- |Rick Cross, 54, male ||{{dts|September 7, 2014}}|| Wild || [[Kananaskis Country]], [[Alberta]]|| Cross, a hunter, was killed by a mother bear when he accidentally got between her and her cubs. Park rangers stated that it appeared that Cross managed to fire his rifle before being overwhelmed. RCMP said it appeared he wandered into the area where the mother and cub were feeding on a dead deer.{{cite web|title=Rick Cross, missing Kananaskis hunter, killed in bear attack|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/rick-cross-missing-kananaskis-hunter-killed-in-bear-attack-1.2760221|website=[[CBC.ca]]|accessdate=25 September 2014}} |- |Adam Thomas Stewart, 31, male ||{{dts|September 4, 2014}}|| Wild || [[Bridger-Teton National Forest]], [[Wyoming]]||Stewart was conducting research alone in the Bridger-Teton National Forest in northwest [[Wyoming]] near the SE corner of Yellowstone National Park. This is high density bear habitat and he was in Cub Creek. After he failed to return, a search found his body.{{cite web|last1=Moen|first1=Bob|title=Bear Attack in Wyoming Kills Utah Man|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/bear-attack-wyoming-kills-utah-man-25517661|website=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[ABC.com]]|accessdate=23 September 2014}} The coroner suspects it was a grizzly bear, but the species hasn't officially been determined. The pathologist noted premortem punctures to Stewart's skull, indicating the cause of death was from a bear attack. The FWS report says he was not carrying bear spray or a firearm.https://www.fws.gov/mountain-prairie/es/species/mammals/grizzly/board%20of%20review%20report%20Stewart%202014%20final.pdf |- |Richard White, 49, male ||{{dts|August 24, 2012}}|| Wild || [[Denali National Park]], [[Alaska]]||White was backpacking alone along the [[Toklat River]]. After hikers found an abandoned backpack and torn clothing, rangers investigated and found a male grizzly bear sitting on White's remains. The bear was shot and killed by an [[Alaska State Troopers|Alaska State Trooper]]. A [[necropsy]] of the bear and photographs recovered from White's camera confirmed the attack.{{cite web|title=Bear kills hiker in Denali|url=http://newsminer.com/view/full_story/19930629/article-Bear-kills-hiker-in-Denali?instance=home_news_window_left_top_1|work=[[Fairbanks Daily News-Miner]]|accessdate=26 August 2012|date=25 August 2012}} The photographs in White's camera showed that he was taking photos of the bear in a span of eight minutes from {{convert|50|yd}} to {{convert|100|yd}}.{{cite news|title=Site of deadly Alaska bear mauling remains closed as investigation continues|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/site-of-deadly-alaska-bear-mauling-remains-closed-as-investigation-continues-1110-167507355.html?device=mobile|work=Associated Press|publisher=[[Winnipeg Free Press]]|accessdate=27 August 2012}} It was the first fatal bear attack recorded in Denali National Park. |- |Tomas Puerta, 54, male ||{{dts|October, 2012}}|| Wild || [[Chichagof Island]], [[Alaska]]||After passers-by spotted an unattended skiff, they investigated and encountered a grizzly bear sow and two cubs. Alaska State troopers and [[Sitka, Alaska|Sitka]] Mountain rescue personnel then found evidence of a campsite and fire on the beach. There was evidence of a struggle, and upon following a trail of disturbed vegetation, they found Puerta's body, cached and partially eaten.{{cite web|title=Chichagof Island, Alaska: Bears Likely Attacked Tomas Puerta, Forestry Worker |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/10/16/chichagof-island-alaska-bear-attack_n_1968903.html|accessdate=27 July 2014|date=15 October 2012|publisher=[[Associated Press]]}} |- |John Wallace, 59, male ||{{dts|August 24, 2011}}|| Wild || [[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]] || Wallace's remains were found by hikers on the Mary Mountain Trail, northeast of [[Old Faithful]].{{cite web|last=Shaylor|first=Jay|title=Man Killed by Grizzly in Yellowstone Visiting 'Place He Loved,' Family Says|url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/man-killed-grizzly-yellowstone-visiting-place-loved-family/story?id=14410813|work=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=30 August 2011|author2=Neil Karlinsky |date=August 30, 2011}} Wallace was hiking alone.{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Matthew|title=Michigan man killed by grizzly in Yellowstone|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/44315237/ns/us_news-life/t/michigan-man-killed-grizzly-yellowstone/#.T5BMCqtYuSo|work=Associated Press|accessdate=29 August 2011}} An autopsy showed that Wallace died from a bear attack. According to a report released by Yellowstone rangers, park officials had attempted to give Wallace a lecture about bear safety, but he was not interested, calling himself a "grizzly bear expert".{{cite news|last=Zuckerman|first=Laura|title=John Wallace, Yellowstone Bear Attack Victim, Called Himself A 'Grizzly Expert'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/03/06/john-wallace-yellowstone-bear-attack_n_1322533.html|work=[[Reuters]]|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=11 November 2013|date=6 March 2012}} DNA evidence later determined that the same sow that killed Brian Matayoshi July 6, 2011 was in the vicinity of Wallace's corpse, though it was not proved that this bear killed Wallace. The bear was killed by park officials. Evidence showed that Wallace was attacked after sitting down on a log to eat a snack and the attack was predatory, rather than defensive.{{cite web|title=2nd Yellowstone grizzly could be killed in mauling of Michigan man|url=http://www.mlive.com/news/index.ssf/2012/03/2nd_yellowstone_grizzly_could.html|work=[[The Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Booth Newspapers]]|accessdate=11 November 2013}} |- |Brian Matayoshi, 57, male ||{{dts|July 6, 2011}}|| Wild || [[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]] || Matayoshi and his wife were hiking the Wapiti Lake Trail, and came upon a mother grizzly bear in an open [[meadow]]. The couple began to walk away, and the bear charged. After attempting to run away, Matayoshi was fatally bitten and clawed. Matayoshi's wife hid behind a tree, was lifted from the ground by the bear, and dropped. She played dead, and the bear left the area. She was not injured.{{cite news|title=Bear acted defensively in attacking hikers, Yellowstone officials say|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-07-07/us/wyoming.grizzly.attack_1_bear-attacks-kerry-gunther-yellowstone-ecosystem?_s=PM:US|work=[[CNN.com]]|accessdate=12 July 2011|date=8 July 2011}}{{cite web|title=Identity of Bear Mauling Victim Released|url=http://www.nps.gov/yell/parknews/11075.htm|work=[[National Park Service]]|last=Cart|first=Julie|accessdate=12 July 2011}} An initial investigation by the [[National Park Service]] found the bear's actions were defensive against a perceived threat to her cubs. Since the attack was not predatory and the bear had no known violent history towards humans, no immediate action was taken towards the bear, the bear was later killed after it was found to be at the site of another fatal attack August 24, 2011. A later investigation determined that the couple running from the bear was a mistake, and the fatal attack was a "one in 3 million occurrence".{{cite news|title=Yellowstone park releases report on grizzly attack|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/greenspace/2011/09/yellowstone-grizzly-mauling.html|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=23 September 2011|date=20 September 2011}} |- | Kevin Kammer, 48, male ||{{dts|July 28, 2010}}|| Wild || [[Gallatin National Forest|Gallatin National Forest, Montana]] || Kammer was in his tent at Soda Butte Campground when a mother bear attacked and dragged him {{convert|25|ft}} away. Two other campers in separate campsites were also attacked: a teenager was bitten in the leg, and a woman was bitten in the arm and leg. The bear was caught in a trap set at the campground using pieces of a [[culvert]] and Kammer's tent.{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Matthew|title=Grizzly caught after MT mauling that killed MI man |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2012476227_apusbearmaulingdeath.html|accessdate=29 July 2010|publisher=The Seattle Times|agency=Associated Press|date=29 July 2010}} Later, the bear was killed, and her cubs were sent to [[ZooMontana]].{{cite news|title=Grizzly Bear Euthanized After Mont. Triple Mauling |url=http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory?id=11287279|agency=Associated Press|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=31 July 2010}} The mother bear's unusual predatory behavior was noted by authorities. |- | Erwin Frank Evert, 70, male ||{{dts|June 17, 2010}}|| Wild ||[[Shoshone National Forest|Shoshone National Forest, Wyoming]]|| Evert, a field botanist, was mauled by a grizzly bear while hiking in the Kitty Creek Drainage area of the Shoshone National Forest, just east of [[Yellowstone National Park]]. The bear was trapped and tranquilized earlier in the day by a grizzly bear research team. Two days after the attack, the bear was shot and killed from a helicopter by wildlife officials.{{cite news|last=Prevost|first=Ruffin|title=Officials kill bear suspected in fatal mauling near Yellowstone|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/wyoming/article_f45a84f8-7bbd-11df-9a95-001cc4c002e0.html |accessdate=19 June 2010|newspaper=Billings Gazette|date=19 June 2010}} Initially it was reported that Evert ignored posted warnings to avoid the area due to the potential danger involved with the bear research. However, the sheriff's deputy who recovered the body and members of Evert's family stated that the warning signs were no longer present.{{cite news|last=Gruver|first=Mead|title=Family Of Man Killed By Bear Says Warnings Removed|date=29 June 2010|url=http://billingsgazette.com/news/state-and-regional/wyoming/article_1753f3dc-83ce-11df-a4db-001cc4c002e0.html|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=2 July 2010}} A report released the following month confirmed that the warning signs were removed, though it also asserted that Evert knew there was a bear research study being conducted in the area.{{cite news|title=Family of man killed by bear says warnings removed|url=http://helenair.com/news/state-and-regional/article_ba851a34-93c0-11df-822d-001cc4c002e0.html|accessdate=9 January 2011|newspaper=[[Billings Gazette]]|date=29 June 2010}} Evert's wife filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the federal government, which was dismissed by district court judge [[Nancy D. Freudenthal]].{{cite news|title=Grizzly mauling lawsuit|url=http://www.powelltribune.com/news/item/8916-grizzly-mauling-lawsuit|accessdate=11 November 2013|newspaper=Powell Tribune|date=27 October 2011}}{{cite news|last=Prevost|first=Ruffin|title=Judge sides with feds in lawsuit over fatal bear mauling near Yellowstone|url=http://www.codyenterprise.com/news/local/article_9e276d9a-1ed5-11e2-b209-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=11 November 2013|newspaper=[[Cody Enterprise]]|date=25 October 2012}} |} ===Polar bear=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:200px;"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Aaron Gibbons, 31, male || {{dts|July 3, 2018}} || Wild || [[Sentry Island]], [[Nunavut]] ||A polar bear approached a man and his children on Sentry Island. The man, identified as 31-year-old Aaron Gibbons from [[Arviat]], put himself between the children and the bear and was attacked, causing fatal injuries. The bear was killed by other people who were also in the area.{{cite news|url=https://bnonews.com/site/index.php/2018/07/canadian-man-killed-in-rare-polar-bear-attack/|title=Canadian man killed in rare polar bear attack| work=[[BNO News]] | date=July 4, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/polar-bear-attack-arviat-1.4733550|title=Man killed in polar bear attack 'died a hero,' says cousin| work=[[CBC News]] | date=July 4, 2018}} |} ==2000s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Kelly Ann Walz, 37, female ||{{dts|October 4, 2009}}|| Captive|| [[Ross Township, Monroe County, Pennsylvania|Ross Township]], [[Pennsylvania]] || Walz, whose husband had an expired license to keep exotic animals, was attacked while cleaning her pet bear's cage. She tried to distract the bear by throwing dog food to the opposite end of the cage. A neighbor shot and killed the bear.{{cite web|title=Kelly Ann Walz killed by her pet black bear|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/unleashed/2009/10/kelly-ann-walz-killed-by-her-pet-black-bear.html|website=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=25 September 2014}} |- | Donna Munson, 74, female ||{{dts|August 6, 2009}}|| Wild || [[Ouray, Colorado]] || Munson had been feeding bears for a decade, and was repeatedly warned by wildlife officials. After a bear was injured in a fight with an older and bigger bear, Munson left food out to help the injured bear. The older bear came back to Munson's property, forced its way past a wire fence, and mauled Munson. Later, wildlife officials killed two bears on Munson's property. One of the bears had a [[necropsy]] which revealed evidence that it consumed Munson.{{cite news | url=http://www.denverpost.com/frontpage/ci_13034073 | title=Autopsy: Bear killed woman near Ouray| work=[[The Denver Post]]| date=August 11, 2009 | last=Bunch | first=Joey}}{{cite web|last=Harrison|first=Wayne|title=Autopsy: Woman Attacked, Killed By Bear|url=http://www.thedenverchannel.com/news/20348401/detail.html|work=The Denver Channel|publisher=[[KMGH-TV]]|accessdate=9 January 2011}} |- | Cécile Lavoie, 70, female ||{{dts|May 30, 2008}}|| Wild || near [[La Sarre, Quebec]]|| After Lavoie didn't return to her cabin following a solo fishing outing, her husband went looking for her. He found a bear dragging her body into the woods.{{cite news|title=Killer bear hunted in Quebec|url=http://www.canada.com/windsorstar/news/story.html?id=fca20e57-61a9-454d-a6ef-29fdc2e409f8|accessdate=25 June 2010|newspaper=The Windsor Star|date=3 June 2008}} |- | Robin Kochorek, 31, female ||{{dts|July 20, 2007}}|| Wild || [[Panorama Mountain Village|Panorama Mountain Resort]], [[British Columbia]] || Kochorek was reported missing after [[mountain biking]]. A black bear was found near her corpse the morning after her disappearance. The bear was shot on sight by the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP).{{cite news|title='Aggressive bear' killed Calgary cyclist near B.C. resort|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/aggressive-bear-killed-calgary-cyclist-near-b-c-resort-1.670727|work=CBC|accessdate=20 August 2010 | date=July 25, 2007}} |- | Samuel Evan Ives, 11, male ||{{dts|June 17, 2007}}|| Wild ||[[Uinta National Forest|Uinta National Forest, Utah]]||Ives was grabbed from a family tent in [[American Fork Canyon]], and mauled. State wildlife officials killed the bear, which had entered the campsite the night before.{{cite news | url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/1,5143,665194630,00.html | last=Walch |first=Tad |title=Boy attacked in tent and killed by black bear near campground | publisher=Deseret Morning News | date=June 18, 2007}} Ives' family sued the [[U.S. Forest Service]] because there was no warning about the bear's presence.{{cite news|last=Meyers|first=Donald|title=High court: State can be sued for bear attack|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/home/50737680-76/state-court-bear-family.html.csp|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|date=23 November 2010}}{{cite news|last=Pyrah|first=Joe|title=Family files lawsuits over fatal bear attack |url=http://www.heraldextra.com/news/local/article_794eb390-9401-537e-be51-5f7dc8ad89e3.html|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=[[Daily Herald (Utah)|Daily Herald]]|date=28 March 2008}} A judge awarded the family $1.95 million.{{cite news|last=Belluck|first=Pam|title=Study of Black Bears Finds It's Not the Mamas That Should Be Feared the Most|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/11/science/11bears.html|accessdate=11 May 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 May 2011}} It was the first known fatal black bear attack in Utah. |- | Elora Petrasek, 6, female ||{{dts|April 13, 2006}}|| Wild || [[Cherokee National Forest|Cherokee National Forest, Tennessee]]||A bear attacked the family at a waterfall near a campground. Petrasek's mother and brother were also injured. The bear was trapped and killed, and an unrelated bear was mistakenly killed.{{cite news | url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2006-04-14-bear-attack_x.htm | title=Tenn. mountains searched for bear that mauled family | agency=Associated Press | publisher=USA Today | date=April 15, 2006}}{{cite web|last=Turner|first=Karl|title=Woman visits site of fatal bear attack|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2008/04/woman_visits_site_of_fatal_bea.html|work=Cleveland.com|accessdate=12 July 2010}}{{cite news|last=Striker|first=Clarissa|title=Wrong Bear Killed After Mauling |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2006/06/14/national/main1712223.shtml|work=CBSNews.com|accessdate=1 January 2011|date=14 June 2006}} |- | Jacqueline Perry, 30, female ||{{dts|September 6, 2005}}|| Wild ||[[Missinaibi River|Missinaibi Lake Provincial Park]], [[Ontario]]|| Perry was killed in an attack at a remote campsite.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/black-bear-kills-woman-camper-north-of-chapleau-ont-1.556281|work=CBC News | title=Black bear kills woman camper north of Chapleau, Ont. | date=September 7, 2005}} Her husband was seriously injured trying to protect her with a [[Swiss Army knife]], and later was given a [[Star of Courage (Canada)|Star of Courage award]] from [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Michaëlle Jean]].{{cite news|last=Boyle|first=Theresa|title=A hero with one big regret|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/article/217195--a-hero-with-one-big-regret|accessdate=21 March 2011|newspaper=[[The Toronto Star]]|date=24 May 2007}} [[Ministry of Natural Resources (Ontario)|Ministry of Natural Resources]] staff shot and killed the bear near the area where the fatal attack occurred.{{cite web|last=Helwig|first=David|title=Province destroys bear believed responsible for park killing|url=http://www.sootoday.com/content/news/full_story.asp?StoryNumber=13270|work=[[SooToday.com]]|accessdate=21 March 2011}} |- | Harvey Robinson, 69, male ||{{dts|August 26, 2005}}|| Wild || [[Selkirk, Manitoba]] || Robinson was fatally mauled while picking plums north of [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]]. Robinson's family were investigating the area with an RCMP officer later that day, and were also attacked. The officer shot and killed the bear.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20050828/bear_attack_050827?s_name=&no_ads=|title=Hiker in stable condition after grizzly attack|date=August 28, 2005|work=CTV.ca News Staff|publisher=CTV.ca|accessdate=2008-10-20}} |- | Merlyn Carter, 71, male ||{{dts|June 14, 2005}}|| Wild ||[[Nonacho Lake]], [[Northwest Territories]]|| Carter was found dead behind the main cabin of his fishing camp. Carter's son came to the cabin the day after the attack, and shot and killed the bear.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/bear-mauls-n-w-t-pilot-to-death-1.523011|title=Bear mauls N.W.T. pilot to death|date=June 17, 2005|work=CBC News|accessdate=2008-10-20}} |- | Maurice Malenfant, 77, male ||{{dts|September 29, 2002}}|| Wild || [[Saint-Zénon-du-Lac-Humqui, Quebec]] || Malenfant was attacked in his campsite in the Gaspé region of [[Quebec]].{{cite news|title=Regional Report|newspaper=[[Windsor Star]]|date=1 October 2002|page=C1}}{{cite web|last=Turmel|first=Gilles|title=Un septuagénaire est tué par un ours en Gaspésie|url=http://www.canoe.com/archives/lcn/infos/faitsdivers/2002/09/20020930-084652.html|work=Canoe.ca|accessdate=7 July 2010|language=French}} |- | Christopher Bayduza, 31, male ||{{dts|September 1, 2002}}|| Wild || near [[Fort Nelson, British Columbia]] || After going for a walk behind a trailer, Bayduza was attacked at a remote oil rigging site in northeastern [[British Columbia]].{{cite news|last=Read|first=Nicholas|title=Bear kills oil rig worker in northern B.C.|newspaper=Vancouver Sun|date=September 4, 2002}}{{cite journal|title=Bear attack claims life of oil rig worker|journal=OHS Canada|date=October 2002|url=http://www.ohscanada.com/issues/story.aspx?aid=1000191409&type=Print%20Archives|accessdate=30 November 2010}} |- | Ester Schwimmer, 5 months, female ||{{dts|August 19, 2002}}|| Wild ||[[Fallsburg, New York]] || A bear knocked Schwimmer from her stroller, which was near the porch of her family's vacation home. The bear carried the infant in its mouth to the woods. Schwimmer died of neck and head injuries.{{cite news|last=Hancock|first=David|title=Bear Kills Baby In Upstate N.Y.|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2002/08/20/national/main519289.shtml|work=CBSNews|accessdate=7 July 2010 | date=2002-08-20}} |- | Adelia Maestras Trujillo, 93, female ||{{dts|August 18, 2001}}|| Wild || [[Mora, New Mexico]] ||A bear broke through a glass pane to gain entry into Trujillo's house and killed her. Trujillo's body was found in her kitchen. The bear was shot {{convert|.5|mi|km}} from the house.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/sep/09/local/me-43719|title=Neighbors Mourn Victim of Rare Bear Attack|last=Baker|first=Deborah |date=September 9, 2001|accessdate=2008-10-20 | work=The Los Angeles Times}} |- | Kyle Harry, 18, male ||{{dts|June 3, 2001}}|| Wild || near [[Yellowknife, Northwest Territories]]||Harry was attacked while with a group at a rural campsite {{convert|25|km}} east of Yellowknife in the [[Northwest Territories, Canada]].{{cite news|work=Canadian Press|title=Wrong bear shot after teen mauled to death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1638&dat=20010605&id=5ik6AAAAIBAJ&sjid=PioMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2288,7044575|accessdate=18 June 2010|publisher=Cobalt Daily Nuggei|date=June 5, 2001}} |- | Mary Beth Miller, 24, female ||{{dts|July 2, 2000}}|| Wild || near [[Saint-Gabriel-de-Valcartier|Valcartier]], [[Quebec]] || Miller was attacked while on a [[biathlon]] training run in a wooded area on a military base. The bear was trapped and killed four days later.{{cite news|title=Bear killed Mary Beth Miller|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/bear-killed-mary-beth-miller-1.216612|work=CBC News|accessdate=7 July 2010 | date=July 6, 2000}} |- | Glenda Ann Bradley, 50, female ||{{dts|May 21, 2000}} || Wild ||[[Great Smoky Mountains National Park|Great Smoky Mountains National Park, Tennessee]]||Bradley was attacked and partially consumed by a mother bear and a cub, {{convert|1.5|mi|km}} upstream from [[Elkmont, Tennessee]]. It was the first fatal bear attack in a southeastern [[List of areas in the United States National Park System|U.S. National Park]]. While hovering over Bradley's corpse, the bears were shot and killed by [[park rangers]].{{cite news|last=Simmons|first=Morgan|title=Mauling of woman won't change park's bear-management policy |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GSIqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sS8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6831,4613259|accessdate=10 January 2011|newspaper=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|date=24 May 2000}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Robert Wagner, 48, male ||{{dts| October 1, 2008}}|| Wild|| near [[Sundre, Alberta]] || Wagner was reported missing after not returning from a hunting trip. His body was found less than {{convert|1|km|adj=off}} from his parked truck. An autopsy revealed that he had been killed by a grizzly bear, which was shot by wildlife officers.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/grizzly-that-mauled-hunter-shot-1.701971| title=Grizzly that mauled hunter shot| work=CBC News| date=October 10, 2008}}{{cite web|title=Sundre residents get the bear facts |url=http://calgary.ctv.ca/servlet/an/local/CTVNews/20081011/CGY_meeting_bear_081011?hub=CalgaryHome|work=CTV.ca|accessdate=25 December 2010}} |- | [[Stephan Miller]], 39, male ||{{dts|April 22, 2008}}|| Captive ||[[Big Bear Lake, California]] || Rocky, bear trained to perform in movies turned on its handler, fatally biting him in the neck. Prior to the attack, the bear was featured in the movie ''[[Semi-Pro]]''. [[Pepper spray]] was used to subdue the bear.{{cite news|title=Grizzly Bear That Appeared in Will Ferrell Film Kills Trainer in California|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,352211,00.html|agency=Associated Press|publisher=Fox News|accessdate=8 July 2010 | date=2008-04-23}}{{cite web |url=http://channel.nationalgeographic.com/episode/grizzly-face-to-face-4969/Photos#tab-Photos/1 |title=Grizzly Face to Face |author= |work= |publisher=National Geographic |accessdate=November 4, 2010}} |- | Don Peters, 51, male ||{{dts|November 25, 2007}}|| Wild || near [[Sundre, Alberta]] || Peters' body was found {{convert|200|m}} from his parked truck. He was on a hunting trip. An autopsy confirmed that he died due to a grizzly bear attack. The bear that attacked Peters was captured and killed the following April.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/missing-calgary-hunter-mauled-by-bear-1.658839 | title=Missing Calgary hunter mauled by bear | work=CBC News| date=November 29, 2007 }}{{cite news|title=Grizzly destroyed after killing hunter last fall |url=http://www.canada.com/calgaryherald/news/city/story.html?id=105d7ca4-4fce-4a6e-a38a-ebfac82ad5b2|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=The Calgary Herald|date=4 April 2008}} |- | Jean-François Pagé, 28, male ||{{dts|April 28, 2006}}|| Wild ||near [[Ross River, Yukon]] || Pagé was mauled while staking mineral claims. He unknowingly walked right past a bear den containing a sow and two cubs.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/north/mining-company-charged-with-negligence-in-yukon-bear-attack-1.645797 | title=Mining company charged with negligence in Yukon bear attack | work =CBC News| date=May 7, 2006}} |- | Arthur Louie, 60, male ||{{dts|September 20, 2005}} || Wild || near [[Bowron River]], [[British Columbia]]|| A female and two cubs attacked Louie on a remote forestry road. He was walking back to his gold mining camp after his car broke down.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/bear-snares-set-in-wake-of-mauling-death-1.530482| title=Bear snares set in wake of mauling death | work=CBC News | date=September 25, 2005}}{{cite news|last=Hansen|first=Darah|title=Invermere man mauled to death by female grizzly|newspaper=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=23 September 2005}} |- | Rich Huffman, 61, male
Kathy Huffman, 58, female ||{{dts|June 23, 2005 }}|| Wild || [[Arctic National Wildlife Refuge|Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, Alaska]]|| The Huffmans were attacked while in their tent at a campsite along the Hulahula River {{convert|12|mi|km}} upriver from [[Kaktovik, Alaska|Kaktovik]].{{cite web|title=Victims of bear attack were wilderness vets |last=Kizzia|first=Tom|date=June 28, 2005|publisher=Anchorage Daily News}} Two days later the campsite was discovered by three rafters while the bear was still nearby. The bear chased the rafters down the river for over half a mile (800 m) until it finally gave up. Later, a [[North Slope Borough]] Police officer investigating the scene shot and killed the bear at the campsite.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalgeographic.com/media/adventure/0510/whats_new/alaska_grizzly_attacks.html|title=ANWR Grizzly Attacks: They Did Everything Right |last=Waterman|first=Jonathan|date=October 2005|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=2010-06-29}} |- | Isabelle Dubé, 35, female ||{{dts|June 5, 2005}} || Wild || [[Canmore, Alberta]] || Dubé was killed while jogging with two friends on the Bench Trail. After an initial attack, Dubé climbed a tree while her friends sought help. The bear brought Dubé down from the tree and mauled her.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,158764,00.html|title=Grizzly Bear Kills Woman in Canada|date=June 6, 2005|agency=Associated Press|publisher=FoxNews|accessdate=2008-10-20}}{{cite news|title=Grizzly mauls female jogger to death on Alberta trail|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=I9VYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=s_ADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3450,1636766|accessdate=10 January 2011|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=7 June 2005}} Fish and wildlife officers shot and killed the bear. At the time of the attack, the trail was closed, and the public had been told to avoid it.{{cite web|title=Bear attack victim on closed trail: officials|url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/CTVNewsAt11/20050607/grizzly_attack_050606/|work=[[CTV.ca]]|accessdate=10 January 2011|archive-date=2010-09-21|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921045353/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/CTVNewsAt11/20050607/grizzly_attack_050606/}} A few days earlier, the bear had been relocated from Canmore to [[Banff National Park]]. |- | [[Timothy Treadwell]], 46, male
Amie Huguenard, 37, female ||{{dts|October 5, 2003}} || Wild || [[Katmai National Park and Preserve|Katmai National Park, Alaska]] || Treadwell and Huguenard's corpses were found by their pilot at Kaflia Bay. Treadwell was famous for his books and documentaries on living with wild bears in Alaska. State Troopers investigating the incident recovered an audiotape of the attack. The two were killed on the last night before their scheduled pickup after spending several months in the Alaskan bush.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/3174636.stm|title= Bear kills campaigner in Alaska|date=October 8, 2003|work=BBC News|accessdate=2009-05-21}} The attack is chronicled in the 2005 American documentary film ''[[Grizzly Man]]'' by German director [[Werner Herzog]]. |- | Timothy Hilston, 50, male ||{{dts|October 30, 2001}} || Wild || near [[Ovando, Montana|Ovando]], [[Montana]]|| Hilston was attacked as he field dressed an [[elk]] in Western Montana.{{cite news|title=Widow of man killed by griz is suing state|url=http://www.greatfallstribune.com/news/stories/20040923/localnews/1285553.html|accessdate=7 July 2010|newspaper=[[Great Falls Tribune]]|date=23 September 2004}} A female bear and her cubs suspected in the attack were killed by [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service|U.S. Fish and Wildlife]] officials.{{cite news|last=Devlin|first=Sherry|title=Killer grizzly bear shot, killed|url=http://helenair.com/news/killer-grizzly-bear-shot-killed/article_8161367e-a052-5ac3-945e-8c55ed8e3c5f.html|accessdate=11 November 2013|newspaper=[[Independent Record]]|date=3 November 2001}} Hilston's widow sued federal and state agencies for negligence, and the lawsuits were dismissed by District Court judge [[Donald W. Molloy]].{{cite web|last=Adams|first=John|title=Bears will be bears|url=http://missoulanews.bigskypress.com/missoula/bears-will-be-bears/Content?oid=1136605|work=[[Missoula Independent]]|accessdate=11 November 2013}} |- | George Tullos, 41, male ||{{dts|July 14, 2000}} || Wild || [[Hyder, Alaska]] || Tullos' partially consumed body was found at a campground near the Canada–US border in [[Alaska Panhandle|Southeast Alaska]]. The bear was shot and killed.{{cite news|title=Brown Bear Killed After Fatal Attack|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l_sxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=n-UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3643,3678673|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=[[Lawrence Journal-World]]|date=18 July 2000}} |} ==1990s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Raymond Kitchen, 56, male
Patti McConnell, 37, female || {{dts|August 14, 1997}} || Wild ||[[Liard River Hot Springs Provincial Park]], [[British Columbia]]|| McConnell died from injuries while defending herself and her son from a black bear attack on a boardwalk to the hot springs. Kitchen heard the attack in progress, and was killed while attempting to rescue. McConnell's son and a 20-year-old man were also injured. The bear was shot while standing over the victims.{{cite news|title=Black Bear Kills Texas Woman, Canadian Man|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/aug/17/news/mn-23311|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=17 August 1997}} McConnell's son received a [[Star of Courage (Canada)|Star of Courage]] for his attempt to save his mother. Kitchen also received the honor, posthumously.{{cite news|title=Texas teen honored for bravery in bear attack|url=http://lubbockonline.com/stories/091998/0919980016.shtml|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Lubbock Avalanche-Journal]]|accessdate=23 September 2011}} |- | Sevend Satre, 53, male|| {{dts|June 14, 1996}} || Wild || near [[Tatlayoko Lake, British Columbia]] ||Satre was killed while checking fence lines near the central [[British Columbia]] community of Tatlayoko Lake, British Columbia.{{cite web|url=http://www.outdoorlife.com/article/Hunting/Black-Bears--Simple-Fools-or-Cunning-Killers|title=Black Bears--Simple Fools or Cunning Killers|last=Shockey|first=Jim|date=April 1, 1999|publisher=Outdoor Life|accessdate=2008-10-20}} |- | Ian Dunbar, 4, male || {{dts|September 16, 1994}} || Wild ||[[70 Mile House, British Columbia]]||Dunbar was attacked in the back yard of his home. The bear was later killed by conservation officers.{{cite news|title=4-year-old Boy Dies After Bear Mauling|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=31NWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-usDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3060,4635456|accessdate=19 April 2012|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=21 September 1994}} |- | Colin McClelland, 24, male || {{dts|August 10, 1993}} || Wild ||[[Fremont County, Colorado]]||A bear tore open the door to McClelland's trailer and attacked him at Waugh Mountain, [[Colorado]]. The bear was later killed by game wardens. |- | Darcy Staver, 33, female || {{dts|July 8, 1992}} || Wild ||[[Glennallen, Alaska]] ||The bear entered her cabin and Staver and her husband fled to the roof. While Staver's husband went for help, the bear killed her. The bear was shot and killed by a neighbor.{{cite news | url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920709&slug=1501334 | title=Ft. Lewis Woman Killed By Bear At Alaskan Cabin | publisher=The Seattle Times | date=July 9, 1992}}{{cite news|last=Loy|first=Wesley|title=Bear Attacks On People Prompt Lethal Backlash |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920913&slug=1512666|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=[[Washington Post]]|date=13 September 1992}} |- | Sébastien Lauzier, 20, male || {{dts|June 14, 1992}} || Wild ||near [[Cochrane, Ontario]] ||Lauzier was attacked while taking soil samples. The bear charged at Sébastien Lauzier, 20, of Timmins, as he and a partner from a mineral exploration company were working Sunday. Lauzier's partner, Rod Barber, also of Timmins, was able to drive off the bear with a pole and was not hurt, Sgt. Mike Jordan said. The incident occurred about 92 km (57 miles) northeast of Cochrane, just west of the Quebec border.{{cite news|title=Student Mauled Fatally By Bear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rtkgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LWsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1238,4508973|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=McCook Daily Gazette|date=16 June 1992}} |- | Raymond Jakubauskas, 32, male
Carola Frehe, 48, female ||{{dts|October 11, 1991}} || Wild ||[[Algonquin Provincial Park]], [[Ontario]]||While they were setting up camp on Bates Island, a black bear broke both of their necks. The bear then dragged their bodies into the woods and consumed the remains. When police arrived five days later, the bear was guarding the bodies. A park naturalist called the attack "right off the scale of normal bear behavior".{{cite book|last= MacGregor|first=Roy|title=Escape: In Search of the Natural Soul of Canada|year=2002|publisher=Random House|isbn=0-7710-5601-X|page=92}}{{cite news|last=Wong|first=Tony|title=Man may have fought killer bear|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=19 October 1991}} |- | James Waddell, 12, male || {{dts|May 26, 1991}} || Wild ||[[Lesser Slave Lake]], [[Alberta]]||In the [[Marten River]] Campground, Waddel was dragged from a tent during the night and killed.{{cite news|title=Black Bear Kills Boy in Tent - Attack Baffles Authorities|newspaper=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|date=28 May 1991|page=A4|agency=Reuters}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Ned Rasmussen, 53, male || {{dts|November 1, 1999}} || Wild || [[Uganik Island]], [[Alaska]] ||After Rasmussen disappeared on a deer hunting trip, he was found dead.{{cite web|title=Man dies after mauling |last=Aho|first=Karen|publisher=Anchorage Daily News}} |- | Ken Cates, 53, male || {{dts|May 25, 1999}} || Wild ||[[Kenai National Wildlife Refuge|Kenai National Wildlife Refuge, Alaska]]||Cates was killed while hiking near [[Soldotna, Alaska]] in the Kenai National Wildlife Refuge. Troopers found Cates' rifle, spent shell casings, and blood nearby which suggested that Cates may have shot the bear.{{cite news|title=Bear Kills Alaskan on Kenai Peninsula|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/may/27/news/mn-41666|accessdate=8 July 2010|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|work=[[Reuters]]|date=27 May 1999}}{{cite news|title=Man mauled to death by bear during hike|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=27 May 1999}} |- | George Evanoff, 65, male || {{dts|October 24, 1998}} || Wild || near [[Prince George, British Columbia]] || Evanoff was hiking on the Bearpaw Ridge, {{convert|72|km|mi}} northeast of Prince George, British Columbia. He encountered a grizzly feeding on a moose kill about a half-mile (800 m) from his cabin. He was bitten on the neck, but his body was not mauled or eaten by the bear.{{cite book|last=Nash|first=Mike|title=The Mountain Knows No Expert: George Evanoff, Outdoorsman and Contemporary Hero|year=2009|publisher=Dundurn Press Ltd.|isbn=1-55002-868-5|page=253|url=https://books.google.com/?id=y915oy8CYbcC&lpg=PA10&dq=George%20Evanoff%20british%20columbia&pg=PA253}}{{cite news|title=B.C. Hiker Is Killed By Grizzly Bear|url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19981026&slug=2779813|accessdate=12 December 2010|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=26 October 1998}} |- | Christopher Kress, 40, male || {{dts|August 22, 1998}} || Wild || near [[Beaver Mines, Alberta]] ||Kress was killed by a grizzly bear while fishing on the South Castle River, near the Beaver Mines campground in Alberta.{{cite news|last=Henton|first=Darcy|title=On the prowl|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=26 August 1998}}{{cite web|title=Echoes from|url=http://www.pinchercreekecho.com/ArticleDisplay.aspx?archive=true&e=1961970|work=The Pincher Creek Echo|accessdate=12 December 2010}} |- | Craig Dahl, 26, male || {{dts|May 17, 1998}} || Wild || [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]||Dahl's partially consumed remains were found three days after he set off to hike alone in the [[Two Medicine]] area of Glacier National Park. He was attacked by a mother and her two cubs.{cite news|last=Milstein|first=Michael|title=Grizzly Encounters Baffle Park Rangers|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-HcVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=t-sDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6283,3374149|accessdate=25 December 2010|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=13 September 1998}} |- | Audelio Luis Cortes, 40, male || {{dts|February 8, 1998}} || Wild ||near [[Kenai, Alaska]] ||Cortes was killed immediately after being bitten in the head while laying seismic line in the [[Swanson River]] area. His crew walked past the bear's den.{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Residents demand death for killer bear|url=http://www.juneauempire.com/stories/021198/bear.html|accessdate=7 July 2010|newspaper=[[Juneau Empire]]|date=11 February 1998}}{{cite web|last=Hermanek|first=Phil|title=Soldotna man OK after bear mauling|url=http://www.peninsulaclarion.com/stories/031704/new_031704new002001.shtml|work=Kenai Peninsula Online|accessdate=23 March 2011}} |- | Robert Bell, 33, male || {{dts|August 23, 1996}}|| Wild || [[Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve|Gates of the Arctic National Park]], Alaska||Bell was killed while hiking with a friend near the Kugrak river. They startled a mother bear feeding on salmon.{{cite news|title=Grizzly Attacks, Kills Hiker|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19960827&id=RABRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=NesDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5105,7082445|accessdate=15 January 2014|newspaper=[[The Register-Guard]]|date=27 August 1996}} |- | Christine Courtney, 32, female || {{dts|July 5, 1996}}|| Wild || [[Kluane National Park|Kluane National Park, Yukon]]||Courtney was killed while hiking on the Slim's Valley trail in Kluane National Park. Her husband was also attacked but survived. [[Park rangers|Park wardens]] killed the bear.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/08/04/world/after-fatal-mauling-in-canada-too-many-bears.html|title=After Fatal Mauling in Canada: Too Many Bears? |last=Farnsworth|first=Clyde|date=August 4, 1996|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2008-10-20}} |- | Shane Fumerton, 32, male
Bill Caspell, 40, male || {{dts|October 9, 1995}} || Wild || near [[Radium Hot Springs, British Columbia]] ||Fumerton and Caspell were killed while securing an elk in the vicinity of Mount Soderhome, in the [[Southern Rocky Mountain Trench]] in southeastern British Columbia.{{cite web|title=Grizzly Bear and Cubs are Shot After 2 Hunters Mauled to Death|date=October 19, 1995|publisher=Seattle Post-Intelligencer}}{{cite book|last=McMillion|first=Scott|title=Mark of the Grizzly: True Stories of Recent Bear Attacks and the Hard Lessons Learned|year=1998|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=1-56044-636-6|page=169|url=https://books.google.com/?id=edKX8lRjoxgC&pg=PA169&lpg=PA169}} |- | Marcie Trent, 77, female
Larry Waldron, 45, male ||{{dts|July 1, 1995}} || Wild || near [[Anchorage, Alaska]] || Trent and her son Waldron were killed by a bear defending a moose carcass while they were hiking on the McHugh Creek Trail in [[Chugach State Park]], near Anchorage, Alaska.{{cite web|url=http://www.adn.com/bearattacks/story/204077.html|title=Mauling deaths mark 1st no-sighting of bear that killed runners|last=Komarnitsky|first=S.J.|publisher=Anchorage Daily News|accessdate=2008-10-20}} |- | John Petranyi, 40, male || {{dts|October 3, 1992}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]] ||Petranyi was killed by a mother with two cubs on the Loop Trail, near the [[Granite Park Chalet]].{{cite news|title=Rangers to kill bears in mauling|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2KIaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=lSwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6418,5859376|accessdate=8 July 2010|publisher=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|agency=Associated Press|author=Journal Staff|date=6 October 1992}} |- | Trevor Percy-Lancaster, 40, male || {{dts|September 15, 1992}} || Wild ||[[Jasper National Park|Jasper National Park, Alberta]] ||Percy-Lancaster and his wife were setting up camp in an isolated area of the [[Tonquin Valley]]. They surprised a bear, and began running away. The bear initially caught Percy-Lancaster's wife, and then he distracted the bear, which turned on him.{{cite news|last=Cusick|first=James|title=British tourist mauled to death by grizzly bear |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/british-tourist-mauled-to-death-by-grizzly-bear-1552049.html|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Independent]]|date=18 September 1992|location=London}}{{cite news|title=Dead husband hailed as a hero for saving wife from grizzly bear |newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=18 September 1992}} |- | Anton Bear, 6, male ||{{dts|July 10, 1992}}|| Wild ||near [[King Cove, Alaska]] ||The six-year-old, his mother, and sister were walking down a road when they were approached by a grizzly that had just been feeding at the town [[Landfill|dump]]. The family fled, but the boy was chased down by the bear and killed. The bear devoured most of the victim before villagers could kill the animal.{{cite news | url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19920913&slug=1512666 | title=Bear Attacks On People Prompt Lethal Backlash | publisher=The Seattle Times | date=July 13, 1992 | first=Wesley | last=Loy}} |} ===Polar bear=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width:200px;"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Hattie Amitnak, 64, female || {{dts|July 9, 1999}} || Wild || near [[Rankin Inlet]], [[Nunavut]] ||Amitnak was mauled after trying to distract a bear that attacked and injured two other people at a [[Hudson Bay]] camp.{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/woman-dead-2-injured-in-polar-bear-attack-1.175863|title=Woman dead, 2 injured in polar bear attack| work=CBC News | date=July 9, 1999}} She was later awarded a posthumous medal of bravery by then-[[Governor-General]] of [[Canada]], [[Adrienne Clarkson]].{{cite news|title=Kivalliq residents lauded for courage|url=http://www.nunatsiaqonline.ca/archives/nunavut001231/nvt21215_06.html|accessdate=9 July 2010|newspaper=[[Nunatsiaq News]]|date=15 December 2000}} |- | Carl Stalker, 28, male || {{dts|December 8, 1990}} || Wild || [[Point Lay, Alaska]] ||While Stalker was walking with his girlfriend, he was chased and consumed in the middle of the town. The bear was shot and killed near Stalker's corpse.{{cite news|title=Alaska Polar Bear Hunted Down Following Deadly Attack -- Animal Had Dragged Away Villager |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19901212&slug=1109098|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=12 December 1990}} |} ==1980s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Gordon Ray, 24, male|| {{dts|May 29, 1985}} || Wild ||near [[Fort Nelson, British Columbia]] || Ray was killed while on a tree planting project approximately {{convert|45|km}} south of Fort Nelson. He climbed a tree to avoid the bear, but fell, and was attacked. The bear was later shot by a helicopter pilot.{{cite news|title=Gun Call Rejected After Mauling|newspaper=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=1 June 1985}} |- | Daniel Anderson, 12, male|| {{dts|July 6, 1983}} || Wild ||[[La Vérendrye Wildlife Reserve|La Vérendrye Wildlife Reserve, Quebec]] || Anderson was grabbed from his tent while camping. His body was found {{convert|100|ft}} from the tent.{{cite news|last=Miller|first=Jacquie|title=Boys Home Safe After Friend's Death |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8K4yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-e4FAAAAIBAJ&pg=1454,2744228&hl=en|accessdate=16 July 2010|newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=7 July 1983|author2=Jane Defalco}} |- | Melvin Rudd, 55, male|| {{dts|May 27, 1983}} || Wild || near [[Narrow Hills Provincial Park|Nipawin Provincial Park]], [[Saskatchewan]] || Rudd was killed while fishing in central Saskatchewan.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&pg=PA103&lpg=PA103|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|page=103|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero}} |- | Clifford David Starblanket, 26, male|| {{dts|May 21, 1983}} || Wild || near [[Canwood, Saskatchewan]] || Starblanket, a [[Animal trapping|trapper]] living in the forest, suffered an attack to his throat and head.{{cite news|last=Vance|first=Catherine|title=Mauling Deaths First In Province|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aZlVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LkANAAAAIBAJ&pg=2826,3836308&hl=en|accessdate=18 December 2010|newspaper=[[The Leader-Post]]|date=31 May 1983}} |- | Lee Randal Morris, 44, male
Carol Marshall, 24, female|| {{dts|August 14, 1980}} || Wild || near [[Zama City]], [[Alberta]] || Morris and Marshall were killed by the same bear in separate attacks over a span of two hours. They were working at a remote oil drilling camp.{{cite news|title=Vicious bear attack leaves two dead|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0LtjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mXoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=942,580147|accessdate=6 January 2011|newspaper=[[The StarPhoenix]]|date=18 August 1980}} |- |Allan Russell Baines, 10, male||{{dts|July 18, 1980}} || Wild || near [[Granisle, British Columbia]]|| Baines was killed on a fishing trip with two friends.{{cite book|last=Marty|first=Sid|title=The Black Grizzly of Whiskey Creek|year=2008|publisher=[[McClelland & Stewart]]|isbn=0771056990|page=49}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Harley Seivenpiper, 40, male || {{dts|November 4, 1988}} || Wild ||[[Port Alexander, Alaska]]|| Seivenpiper was killed while hunting alone. The bear dragged Seivenpiper's body almost {{convert|1|mi|adj=on}} uphill to a cache. When searchers approached the cache, the bear charged, and was shot and killed.{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Alaskan Hunter Killed|newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|date=8 November 1988}}{{cite news|last=Medred|first=Craig|title=Bear attack leaves one dead, another hurt|url=http://www.adn.com/2007/04/17/203990_bear-attack-leaves-one-dead-another.html|accessdate=24 June 2010|newspaper=[[Anchorage Daily News]]}} |- | Gary Goeden, 29, male || {{dts|July 28, 1987}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]|| Goeden's partially consumed remains were found at Natahki Lake, [[Many Glacier|Many Glacier Valley]], [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]]. He was on a solo hike, and off-trail.{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Bear Attack Suspected In State Hiker's Death In Glacier Park|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=j10aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-ioEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7124,3466477|accessdate=24 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|date=5 September 1987}} |- | Charles Gibbs, 40, male || {{dts|April 25, 1987}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]|| Gibbs was last seen alive following and photographing a bear with cubs at Elk Mountain in [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]]. Investigators recovered film of the female approaching in attack mode at {{convert|50|yd}}.{{cite news|work=Associated Press|publisher=Spokesman-Review|title=Photographer killed by bear in Glacier National Park|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=RPwRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fu8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=7022,5942379|accessdate=12 July 2010|date=27 April 1987}}{{cite news|title=Late photographer's bear pictures appear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=XucRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ge8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5913,8593063|publisher=Spokesman-Review|accessdate=12 July 2010|date=15 August 1987}} |- | William Tesinsky, 38, male || {{dts|October 5, 1986}} || Wild ||[[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]]||Tesinkey, a photographer, was mauled after approaching a bear in the Otter Creek area of [[Hayden Valley]], Yellowstone National Park. The bear was killed.{{cite news|title= Park's Chief Ranger Hits And Misses In Book On Yellowstone|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ArciAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JbUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3427,5055025|accessdate=12 July 2010|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Beaver County Times]]|date=31 July 1991}}{{cite news|title=Killer grizzly bear identified|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=P1ghAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jIUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4681,1023205|accessdate=19 December 2010|newspaper=Tri City Herald|date=19 October 1986}} |- | Brigitta Fredenhagen, 25, female || {{dts|July 30, 1984}} || Wild || [[Yellowstone National Park]]|| Fredenhagen was dragged from her tent during the night and killed at a backcountry campsite at the southern end of White Lake in Yellowstone National Park.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=60–61|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&pg=PA60&lpg=PA60}}{{cite news|title=Grizzly killed hiker, board says|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mpAzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=A4MDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3689,5012369|accessdate=11 July 2010|publisher=The Deseret News|work=United Press International|date=27 August 1984}} |- | Roger May, 23, male || {{dts|June 25, 1983}} || Wild || [[Gallatin National Forest]], [[Montana]]|| May was dragged from his tent, and eaten at the Rainbow Point campground, northwest of Yellowstone National Park. The bear was captured and killed with an injection of poison.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=58–60|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&lpg=PA102&pg=PA58#v=onepage&q=roger%20may}}{{cite news|title=Bear kills Yellowstone camper, is put to death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PNkzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IDIHAAAAIBAJ&pg=3038,7122387|accessdate=11 July 2010|publisher=Lodi News-Sentinel|work=United Press International|date=27 June 1983}} |- | Laurence Gordon, 33, male || {{dts|September 30, 1980}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]||Gordon was killed at the Elizabeth Lake campsite in the Belly River Valley, Glacier National Park.{{cite news|title=Ranger shoots suspected grizzly|publisher=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=4 October 1980|agency=Associated Press}}{{cite news|title=Grizzly Bear Shot Near Scene Of Mauling|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ok9OAAAAIBAJ&sjid=We4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2589,3008994|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=[[The Spokesman Review]]|date=6 October 1980}} |- | Ernest Cohoe, 38, male || {{dts|August 24, 1980}} || Wild || near [[Banff, Alberta]] ||While fishing with a friend just north of Banff, Alberta, a bear charged and bit off part of Cohoe's face. He died a week later as a result of the injuries.{{cite news|last=Klaszus|first=Jeremy|title=He's bullish on bears|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/books/hes-bullish-on-bears/article37330/|accessdate=13 July 2010|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=17 May 2008|location=Toronto}}{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|year=2002|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=1-58574-557-X|pages=xiii–xv|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&lpg=PP1&dq=bear%20attacks&pg=PR13#v=onepage&q}} |- | Jane Ammerman, 19, female
Kim Eberly, 19, male || {{dts|July 24, 1980}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]|| Their partially consumed bodies were found near their campsite at Divide Creek in the St. Mary Valley. The bear was later killed by Native American hunters.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=53–54|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&pg=PA53&lpg=PA53}}{{cite news|title=Grizzly Mauls, Kills 2 Campers In Montana|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6mlQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=c1oDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6775,1522377|accessdate=26 December 2010|newspaper=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=26 July 1980}} |} ===Polar bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Juan Perez, 11, male || {{dts|May 19, 1987}} || Captive || [[Brooklyn, New York]]||Perez was killed by two bears after climbing a fence in [[Prospect Park Zoo]], Brooklyn, New York. The bears were killed by police officers.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/05/20/nyregion/polar-bears-kill-a-child-at-prospect-park-zoo.html?pagewanted=1|title=Polar Bears kill a child at Prospect Park Zoo|last=Barron|first=James|date=May 20, 1987|work=The New York Times|accessdate=3 May 2010}} |- | Thomas Mutanen, 46, male || {{dts|November 29, 1983}} || Wild ||[[Churchill, Manitoba]]||Mutanen was attacked and dragged on a street in Churchill. The bear was part of an annual migration to [[Hudson Bay]]. Due to a lack of ice on the bay, the bear wandered into the town.{{cite news|title=Polar Bear Mauls Man to Death on City Street|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=psYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fbkFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2532,4952051|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[Montreal Gazette]]|date=30 November 1983}} |- | Conrado Mones, 29, male || {{dts|September 27, 1982}} || Captive ||[[New York City]]||Mones was mauled after climbing three fences in New York City's [[Central Park Zoo]] to enter the bear's pen.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hKoRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2ukDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6806,9263983|title=Man Killed in Bear Cage was Immigrant|date=September 28, 1992|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[The Gainesville Sun]]|accessdate=29 April 2010}} |} ==1970s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Lynn Orser, 30, female || {{dts|July 2, 1978}} || Captive||[[King, Ontario]]|| A bear trained to wrestle humans entered its owner's home and attacked the owner's friend, Orser, in her bedroom.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=mYY1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=7aEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2436,629395|title=Wrestler can't explain why trained bear killed|date=July 5, 1978|work=[[The Montreal Gazette]]|publisher=[[Canadian Press]]|accessdate=29 April 2010}} |- | George Halfkenny, 16
Mark Halfkenny, 12
Billy Rhindress, 15 (all male) ||{{dts|May 13, 1978}} || Wild ||[[Algonquin Provincial Park]], [[Ontario]] || The three boys were stalked and killed while fishing near Radiant Lake in Algonquin Provincial Park. This was the first fatal bear attack in the park in eighty years.{{cite news|last=Harris|first=Lewis|title=Bear kills three boys and a father wonders: Why?|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_TgyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=b6QFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1472%2C496825|accessdate=8 July 2010|newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]]|date=18 May 1978}} |- | Mary Ann Johns, 1||{{dts|August 12, 1975}} || Captive ||[[Stewardson, Illinois]] || While carnival workers were setting up, a bear was taken out of its cage and chained to a tree. Johns, whose parents were carnival workers, walked by and was attacked. The bear had previously attacked children.{{cite news|last=Prater|first=William|title=Concessionaire's Child Killed By Carnival Bear .|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BJpKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ipQMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4836,3158427|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Nashua Telegraph]]|date=14 August 1975}} |- | Victoria Valdez, 4, female || {{dts|May 16, 1974}} || Wild ||[[Glenwood, Klickitat County, Washington|Glenwood, Washington]] ||Valdez was mauled while playing near her home. Her body was found {{convert|200|yd}} from her home. Her father shot and killed a {{convert|250|lb}} bear before finding his daughter's body.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MDgQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FY8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5051,2806729&|title=Glenwood Girl Killed by Bear|date=May 18, 1974|work=United Press International|publisher=Ellensburg Daily Record|accessdate=2009-07-26}} |- | John Richardson, 31, male || {{dts|July 25, 1971}} || Wild || near [[Rocky Mountain National Park]], [[Colorado]]||Richardson was attacked while camping on private property, just west of Rocky Mountain National Park, and north of [[Grand Lake (Colorado)|Grand Lake]]. The bear was later killed by a professional hunter. This was the first fatal black bear attack in Colorado in modern times.{{cite book|last=Evans|first=Joseph|title=Death, Despair, and Second Chances in Rocky Mountain National Park|year=2010|publisher=Big Earth Publishing|isbn=1-55566-440-7|pages=250–251|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j-WSQGGkXTgC&pg=PA250&lpg=PA250}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Monty Adams, 32, male || {{dts|September 15, 1979}} || Wild || near [[Pincher Creek]], [[Alberta]]|| While hunting alone for sheep west of [[Pincher Creek]] in [[Southern Alberta]], Adams was mauled by a grizzly bear. Adams was found by two other hunters, and died when rescuers were removing him from the area.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&pg=PA234|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|page=234|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero}}{{cite news|title=Widow of hunter killed by bear seeks inquiry|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BAtlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bYMNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5914,1417544|accessdate=6 April 2011|newspaper=[[Edmonton Journal]]|date=24 October 1979}} |- | Alison Muser, 5, female || {{dts|July 1, 1977}} || Wild ||[[Waterton Lakes National Park]], [[Alberta]]|| Muser was mauled to death by a black colored Grizzly Bear while playing with her sister near Cameron Creek in Waterton Lakes National Park. She died en route to a [[Calgary]] hospital. The family had just recently moved to Canada from South Africa and was unaware of the danger posed by bears. The family threatened legal action against the park for failing to provide warnings of the dangers posed by the animals.{{cite news|title=Black bear kills girl|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IjNOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ve0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2255,1077313|accessdate=6 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Spokesman-Review]]|date=2 July 1977}} The bear responsible for the attack was killed.{{cite news|title=Parents Will Sue Parks|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TjlgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QXANAAAAIBAJ&pg=1007,1285782|accessdate=6 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Star-Phoenix]]|date=22 July 1977}} |- | Mary Pat Mahoney, 22, female || {{dts|September 23, 1976}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]|| Mahoney was dragged from a tent and killed at [[Many Glacier]] campground. Rangers killed two grizzly bears in the area a few hours after the attack.{{cite news|title=Woman killed in bear attack|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TrASAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4vgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5165,1948896&dq=mary+pat+mahoney&hl=en|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Spokesman-Review]]|accessdate=12 July 2010|date=26 September 1976}}{{cite news|title=Another bear incident reported|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AOURAAAAIBAJ&sjid=m-0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=6981,4545713&dq=mary+pat+mahoney&hl=en|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[Spokesman-Review]]|accessdate=12 July 2010|date=26 September 1976}} |- | Alan Precup, 25, male || September 11, 12, or 13, 1976; exact date unknown || Wild ||[[Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve]], [[Alaska]] || Precup did not return after backpacking in Glacier Bay National Park and Preserve. Days later, searchers found his campsite with his bare skeleton, one intact hand, and both feet still booted.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=67–68|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link = Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&lpg=PA67&dq=Alan%20Precup&pg=PA67#v=onepage&q=Alan%20Precup}} |- | Barbara Chapman, 24, female || {{dts|July 24, 1976}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (Canada)|Glacier National Park of Canada]], [[British Columbia]]||While hiking with a friend in [[British Columbia]]'s Glacier National Park, Chapman rounded a bend to find a grizzly bear charging. The bear first attacked Chapman's friend, who initially resisted, but left him alone after he played dead. The bear then attacked Chapman, who fought back and was quickly killed. Chapman's friend sustained serious injuries, but was able to hike out for help. The grizzly bear that attacked and her three cubs were soon found and killed.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=9–11|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&lpg=PP1&dq=bear%20attacks&pg=PA9#v=onepage&q}}{{cite news|title=Mauling by Bear Fatal|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bXcwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4PgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1992,2395046|accessdate=10 November 2010|newspaper=Spokane Daily Chronicle|date=27 July 1976}} |- | Jay Reeves, 38, male || {{dts|August 1, 1974}} || Wild ||[[Izembek National Wildlife Refuge]], [[Alaska]]|| Reeves was camping alone on the [[Alaskan Peninsula]], near [[Cold Bay, Alaska|Cold Bay]]. A fisherman discovered a camp that looked like it was damaged by a bear, and found only Reeves' shoes. A helicopter spotted and shot a grizzly bear near the camp. Later, they found Reeves' remains, and an autopsy on the bear revealed human remains.{{cite news|title=Bear kills and devours photographer|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eiJlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MogNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4983,1397492|accessdate=6 April 2011|newspaper=[[Edmonton Journal]]|date=6 August 1974}} |- | Wilf Etherington, 51, male || {{dts|September 25, 1973}} || Wild ||[[Banff National Park]], [[Alberta]]|| Etherington, a biologist with the [[Canadian Wildlife Service]], and a photographer were helping with the relocation of a troublesome grizzly bear in Banff National Park. The bear had been recently trapped and sedated. When the two men approached the bear, it charged and attacked Etherington.{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=34–35|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gFlz6UKGqrcC&lpg=PP1&dq=bear%20attacks&pg=PA34#v=onepage&q}}{{cite news|title=Grizzly bear kills biologist|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=phMyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=96EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4413,3105310&dq=wilf+etherington&hl=en|accessdate=13 July 2010|newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]]|date=27 September 1973}} |- | Harry Walker, 25, male || {{dts|June 25, 1972}} || Wild ||[[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]]|| Walker was attacked by a bear that was feeding on food that was left out at his campsite near [[Old Faithful Inn]].{{cite book|last=McMillion|first=Scott|title=Mark of the Grizzly: True Stories of Recent Bear Attacks and the Hard Lessons Learned|publisher=Globe Pequot|year=1998|isbn=1-56044-636-6|url=https://books.google.com/?id=edKX8lRjoxgC&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=Harry+Walker+bear+attack|accessdate=2008-10-20|page=100}} |- | Harvey Cardinal, 40, male || {{dts|January 15, 1970}} || Wild||near [[Fort St. John, British Columbia]] || Cardinal was attacked and partially eaten while hunting near the [[Doig River]]. The bear had a gum infection, and was shot and killed.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q3oyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I7kFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3609,4327721|title=Grizzly bear that ate man had reason to hate world|date=January 19, 1970|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=Montreal Gazette|accessdate=3 May 2010}} |} ===Polar bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Lafayette Herbert, 43, male || {{dts|August 26, 1976}} || Captive ||[[Baltimore, Maryland]]|| Herbert, who had a history of mental illness, was killed after he climbed into the polar bear enclosure at the [[Baltimore Zoo]].{{cite news|title=Man's Body Mauled By Bears in Zoo|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UpsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gegFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3342,185780|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[Gettysburg Times]]|date=28 August 1976}}{{cite news|title=Mauled man still unnamed|newspaper=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|date=28 August 1976}}{{cite news|title=Man Lived Only Two Blocks From Bears|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2205&dat=19760831&id=-okkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=T_UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2065,1423523|accessdate=5 August 2014|work=Baltimore Afro-American|date=Aug 21, 1976|ref=BaltAfro1976}} |- | Richard Pernitzky, 18, male || {{dts|January 5, 1975}} || Wild ||[[Inuvik, Northwest Territories]]|| Pernitzky was mauled at an [[Imperial Oil]] exploration site. The bear was later shot and killed.{{cite news|title=Man mauled by polar bear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LxQyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2qEFAAAAIBAJ&pg=868,1397014|accessdate=11 April 2013|newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]]|date=8 January 1975}} |- | Richard Hale, 19, male || {{dts|January 19, 1972}} || Captive ||[[Toledo, Ohio]]|| Hale's body was found at the bottom of the polar bear [[grotto]] at the [[Toledo Zoo]]. There was evidence that Hale was under the influence of drugs at the time of his attack.{{cite news|title=Zoo Death Still A Mystery; Robber Returns Loot In Holdup|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2AQkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AQIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6732,1853832|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]]|date=24 January 1972}}{{cite news|title=Mauling by Bear ruled Accident|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=MJgrAAAAIBAJ&sjid=mvUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6351,2948743|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Nashua Telegraph]]|date=26 January 1972}} |} ==1960s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Jack Ottertail, 53, male || {{dts|October 1, 1968}} ||Wild||near [[Atikokan, Ontario]] ||Ottertail was killed while on a walk. A bear found near the body was shot and killed.{{cite news|title=Man Found Dead After Bear's Attack|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uA8hAAAAIBAJ&sjid=x3YFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5547,542850|accessdate=20 April 2012|newspaper=[[The Day (New London)|The Day]]|date=3 October 1968}} |- | Susan Duckitt, 11, female || {{dts|August 8, 1967}} ||Wild ||near [[Okanagan Landing, British Columbia]] ||Duckitt and a friend were picnicking by [[Okanagan Lake]]. They went on a walk up a hill and encountered the bear standing on its hind feet. The girls ran away, and Duckitt was caught. A man tracked down the bear and killed it with six shots.{{cite news|title=Bear Kills Girl On Picnic, Then Pays With Own Life .|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zAZSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7zQNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1737,1347911|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Oxnard Press-Courier]]|date=9 August 1967}} |- | [[Phyllis Tremper]], 3, female || {{dts|September 7, 1966}} ||Captive ||[[Prescott, Arizona]] ||A pet bear dragged Tremper into its cage at the Ponderosa Trailer Park in Prescott, Arizona. The bear's owner shot and killed it.{{cite web | url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sf4KAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aFADAAAAIBAJ&pg=6957,6028554| title=Services Set for Tot Killed By Bear|publisher=Evening Prescott Courier|date=Sep 7, 1966|accessdate=2009-07-26}} |- | Vernon Sauvola, 51, male || {{dts|July 2, 1965}} ||Wild ||[[Aitkin, Minnesota]] ||Sauvola was attacked while he was fishing in a stream, and his body was dragged 60 feet (18 m).http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=WinonaA&BaseHref=TWN/1965/07/02&PageLabelPrint=1&EntityId=Ar00112&ViewMode=GIF |- | Sidney Smith, 26, male || {{dts|September 17, 1964}} ||Wild ||near [[Schefferville, Quebec]] ||Smith, a technician on a radar line, was attacked by a black bear in a remote area. There was evidence that Smith tried to defend himself with a hunting knife.{{cite news|title=Canadian Killed by Black Bear|newspaper=[[The Hartford Courant]]|date=20 September 1964|page=35}} |- | William Strandberg, 51, male || {{dts|August 16, 1963}} ||Wild ||near [[Fairbanks, Alaska]] ||A bear killed Strandberg approximately {{convert|160|mi|km}} west of Fairbanks. Strandberg was a member of a prominent Alaskan mining family.{{cite news|title=Hungry Bear Kills Alaskan|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_DsaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=MycEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7091,5356010|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|date=20 August 1963}}{{cite web|title=David Strandberg |url=http://alaskamininghalloffame.org/inductees/strandberg.php|work=Alaska Mining Hall of Fame Foundation|accessdate=1 January 2011}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Wild ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Russell Ringer, 49, male || {{dts|March 31, 1969}} || Captive || [[Fort Leonard Wood, Missouri]] ||Ringer was crushed by his pet bear, which had no teeth or claws, as he entered its cage for a wrestling match at the military base.{{cite news|title=Toothless Bear Kills Trainer|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GnMjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_IwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5469,55563|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[Sarasota Journal]]|date=1 April 1969}} |- | Julie Helgeson, 19, female || {{dts|August 13, 1967}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]||While camping near the [[Granite Park Chalet]], Helgeson was dragged from her tent. Her boyfriend was also severely mauled. This incident became widely known as "Night of the Grizzlies" when two young women were separately attacked in Glacier National Park, Montana, by grizzly bears.{{cite journal|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=25 August 1967|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,841027,00.html|title=Montana: Night of Terror|accessdate=12 July 2010}}{{cite news|last=O'Neill|first=Peggy|title=Documentary revisits Glacier Park's first fatal bear attacks|url=http://helenair.com/lifestyles/article_b0cc3914-5f13-11df-881e-001cc4c03286.html|accessdate=12 July 2010|newspaper=Independent Record|date=14 May 2010}} |- | Michele Koons, 19, female || {{dts|August 13, 1967}} || Wild ||[[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park, Montana]]|| Koons was camping with a group at the Trout Lake campsite. A bear invaded their camp, and while other campers climbed up trees, Koons was caught in her sleeping bag, and attacked. This incident became widely known as "Night of the Grizzlies" when two young women were separately attacked in Glacier National Park, Montana, by grizzly bears. Although Helgeson and Koons were killed on the same night, these were separate attacks by different bears approximately {{convert|9|mi|km}} apart. Both bears were killed two nights after their attacks.{{cite journal|last=Fales|first=E.D.|title=Glacier Park's Great Grizzly Bear Mystery|journal=[[Popular Mechanics]]|date=November 1968 |pages=82–87 220|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FNQDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=RA1-PA82K&pg=RA1-PA82#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=1 January 2011}} |} ===Polar bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Paulosie Meeko, 19, male || {{dts|November 17, 1968}} || Wild || [[Churchill, Manitoba]] ||Meeko's throat was slashed by a polar bear, and he died less than two hours after the attack. The bear was shot by the police.{{cite news|title=Polar Bear Kills Eskimo Student At Churchill|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tMcyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0-wFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3690,17103|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=18 November 1968}} |} ==1950s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Lyndon Hooper, 51, male || {{dts|September 6, 1959}} || Wild||near [[Cadomin, Alberta]] ||Hooper was fishing alone when attacked {{convert|20|mi|km}} from Cadomin, Alberta.
