His mutilated body was found in a stream.{{cite news|title=18 Fatalities In West; Man Clawed By Bear Dies|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=p1NjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IW8NAAAAIBAJ&pg=1773,880483|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Saskatoon Star-Phoenix]]|date=8 September 1959}} Three days later, a forest ranger shot a bear {{convert|.5|mi|km}} from where Hooper's body was recovered.{{cite news|title=Killer Bear Believed Shot|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-GBkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=I3wNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4303,3747089|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Calgary Herald]]|date=17 September 1959}} It was later discovered that the bear's stomach contained human hair.{{cite news|title=Human hair inside bear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lL5UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8DsNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4076%2C1337413|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[The Leader-Post]]|date=7 October 1959}} |- | Barbara Coates, 7, female || {{dts|August 12, 1958}} || Wild||[[Jasper National Park]], [[Alberta]] ||While Coates was picking berries outside of her family's [[Sunwapta Falls]] cottage, a black bear appeared. Coates ran to the cottage, but the bear chased and mauled her.{{cite news|title=Bear Drags Girl to Death, Scared Onlookers 'Freeze'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vrsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0uoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3856,2802853|accessdate=16 July 2010|publisher=[[The Miami Herald]]|agency=Associated Press|date=9 August 1958}} |- | Andrew Mark Palmer, 3, male || {{dts|August 11, 1953}} || Captive||[[Flagstaff, Arizona]] ||While Palmer was playing with his grandparents' pet bear, he was mauled. The bear was shot and killed by a neighbor.{{cite news|title=Chained Pet Bear Kills 3- Year-old Arizona Boy .|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=h7omAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pU0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5083,1642591|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Deseret News]]|date=12 August 1953}} |- | Rudolph Gaier, 50, male || {{dts|November 19, 1952}} || Wild ||near [[Anchorage, Alaska]] || Gaier and a black bear were found dead at a remote mountain cabin. An investigator concluded that Gaier shot the bear after it entered his cabin, and before dying, the bear fatally clawed Gaier.{{cite news|title=Trapper, Bear Fight to Death|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AyVWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xeIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4960,5314162|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=5 January 1953}}{{cite web|title=Anchorage Memorial Park Cemetery|url=http://files.usgwarchives.net/ak/anchorage/cemeteries/amp/aamem28.txt|publisher=USGenWeb Archives|accessdate=21 April 2012}} |- | Robert Huckins, 18, male || {{dts|September 19, 1952}} || Captive ||[[Crawford Notch State Park]], [[New Hampshire]] ||After feeding a bear in its cage, Huckins was chased and killed. The bear also injured three other people, and was eventually shot and killed with thirteen gun shots.{{cite news|title= Bear Kills Youth At Crawford Notch|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ApU0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=dmgFAAAAIBAJ&pg=1824,7282099|accessdate=6 November 2010|newspaper=[[The Lewiston Daily Sun]]|date=20 September 1952}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Sam Adams, 45, male || {{dts|October 27, 1958}} || Wild|| near [[Ovando, Montana]] || Adams was missing after hunting near the [[Continental Divide of the Americas|Continental Divide]] northeast of [[Missoula]]. His body was found smashed in three parts. Laboratory studies showed evidence that Adams was in a fight with the bear, which was described as "probably a grizzly".{{cite news|title=Hunter Loses Death Struggle With Hungry Grizzly|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qPMeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6YoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=1071,1217351|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[Sarasota Journal]]|date=14 July 1959}} |- | Kenneth Scott, 29, male || {{dts|October 22, 1956}} || Wild || near [[Augusta, Montana]] || While elk hunting, a hunter in Scott's group was attacked, and the bear was shot and wounded. When they went back to kill the bear, Scott's gun jammed and the bear mauled him. The bear was later killed by another hunter.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ccIvAAAAIBAJ&sjid=akgDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7097,4659277|title=Montana Hunter Killed By Bear, Another Injured|date=October 22, 1956|work=[[International News Service]]|publisher=[[The Deseret News]]|accessdate=28 April 2010}}{{cite news|title=Big Grizzly Bear Kills One Hunter, Mauls 2nd in Battle|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0KY0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=-WYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6368,1435858|accessdate=23 December 2010|newspaper=[[Kentucky New Era]]|date=22 October 1956}} |- | Paul Lemery, 28, male || {{dts|October 9, 1956}} || Captive || [[Libertyville, Illinois]] || Lemery, an animal trainer, was attacked when taking a bear out of its cage. He was preparing for a television appearance with the bear.{{cite news|title=Bear's Attack Kills Trainer|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=pB8aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cCUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3261,4885661|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|date=10 October 1956}} |- | Willies McBride, ?, male || {{dts|September 19, 1955}} || Wild|| near [[Kantishna, Alaska|Eureka, Alaska]] || McBride was mauled while hunting alone. The bear was not found.{{cite news|title=Grizzly Bear Kills hunter|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vw5WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=auIDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5460,3427059|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[Eugene Register-Guard]]|date=20 September 1955}} |} ==1940s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Carol Ann Pomeranky, 3, female || {{dts|July 7, 1948}} || Wild||[[Marquette National Forest]], Michigan ||Pomeranky was taken by a bear outside of her home on the Marquette National Forest (now the [[Hiawatha National Forest]]) in Michigan. She was dragged {{convert|100|yd}}. The bear was tracked and killed.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8DAuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hdYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3778,3236974|date=July 8, 1942|work=United Press|publisher=The Miami News|accessdate=3 May 2010|title=Posse Wreaks Swift Vengeance}}{{cite book|last=Herrero|first=Stephen|publisher=Globe Pequo|year=2002|pages=91–94|isbn=1-58574-557-X|title=Bear Attacks: Their Causes and Avoidance|author-link=Stephen Herrero}} |- | Anton Rauch, 59, male || {{dts|August 2, 1945}} || Captive ||[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]] ||Rauch, a worker at the Lincoln Park Zoo, was attacked while cleaning the bear's cage.http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=WinonaA&BaseHref=TWH/1945/08/02&PageLabelPrint=2&EntityId=Ar00211&ViewMode=GIF |- | Carl Herrick, 37, male || {{dts|November 23, 1943}} || Wild ||[[Townshend, Vermont|West Townshend, Vermont]] || Herrick was hunting in West Townshend, Vermont, and his body was found with a blackened face and scratches. His rifle and bear tracks were nearby. A theory is that Herrick shot the bear and thought it was dead, and was squeezed to death when he approached.{{cite news|title=Bear Squeezed Man To Death, Theory Of Tragedy In Vermont|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yu4ZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ByMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6146,4722963&dq=killed+by+a+bear&hl=en|accessdate=6 November 2010|newspaper=The Milwaukee Journal|date=26 November 1943}} |} File:Bear yellowstone garbage cropped.jpg|A black bear searching garbage pails in [[Yellowstone National Park]], circa 1905. Bear attacks on humans led to changes in park's garbage management procedures. File:WrestingWithaBear.jpg|A man wrestling with a trained bear. There have been instances of bears killing their trainers. ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Richard Strand, 8, male || {{dts|September 10, 1945}} || Captive ||[[Seattle, Washington]] ||Strand was attacked while playing with a pet bear. The bear also bit a neighbor who attempted to rescue Strand. The bear was taken to [[Woodland Park Zoo]].{{cite news|title=Boy Ripped Fatally by Tame Bear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4rkxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hucFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3303,2298082|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The Miami News]]|date=11 September 1945}}{{cite news|title=Bear Attack Is Fatal to Boy, 8|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1945/09/12/archives/bear-attack-is-fatal-to-boy-8.html|accessdate=1 January 2011|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=11 September 1945}} |- | Richard Havemann, 68, male || {{dts|December 11, 1942}} || Captive ||[[San Diego, California]] ||Havemann, an animal trainer, was attacked by a [[Himalayan brown bear]] at the [[San Diego Zoo]].{{cite news|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|date=21 February 1943|page=14|title=Havemann Victim of Bear}} |- | Martha Hansen, 45, female || {{dts|August 23, 1942}} || Wild ||[[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]]||Hansen left her cabin to go to the [[public toilet|restroom]]. As she rounded a corner, she surprised a bear and was mauled. Hansen was taken to the hospital and died four days later due to injuries sustained during the attack.{{cite book|last=Biel|first=Alice Wondrak|title=Do (not) feed the bears: the fitful history of wildlife and tourists in Yellowstone|year=2006|publisher=University of Kansas Press|isbn=0-7006-1432-X|page=42}}{{cite news|title=Yellowstone Bear Mauls a Woman|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=0mpWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WPUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=1670,4220312|accessdate=7 January 2011|newspaper=[[Spokane Daily Chronicle]]|date=24 August 1942}} Hansen's sister sought, and eventually successfully received compensation for expenses incurred to care for Martha. [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]] signed a bill in 1944 granting the family $1894.95.{{cite journal|last=Wondrak|first=Alice|title=Wrestling with Horace Albright|journal=Forest History Today|date=August 2002|url=http://www.foresthistory.org/Fellowships/Wondrak.pdf|accessdate=11 November 2013}} |- | Thomas Miller, 28, male || {{dts|June 14, 1941}} || Captive ||[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] ||Miller, a carnival employee, was struck on his head by a bear from [[Canada]]. The attack occurred when Miller took the bear out of its cage to perform tricks for his wife.{{cite news|title=Killed by Bear|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ESE_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=s08MAAAAIBAJ&pg=2340,1025788|accessdate=27 October 2010|newspaper=The Windsor Daily Star|date=14 June 1941}} |} ==1930s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | George Langley, 55, male,
James Virtue, 68, male || {{dts|October 15, 1936}}|| Captive||[[Ellsworth, Maine]]|| Langley owned a gas station where he kept the bear. After entering the bear's cage to feed it, Langley and his helper were attacked. The bear was shot and killed.{{cite news|title=Tame Bear Kills Two Men in Cage|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2TkyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=XuQFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5651,4047879|accessdate=27 October 2010|newspaper=Berkeley Daily Gazette|date=15 October 1936}} |- | Clarence Staley, 54, male || {{dts|November 11, 1934}}|| Captive || [[Mankato, Minnesota]]|| Staley was mauled by a bear that he had raised from a cub. The caged bear attacked Staley when he tried to retrieve a purse that had been dropped inside the bear's cage.http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=WinonaA&BaseHref=TWH/1934/11/12&PageLabelPrint=1&EntityId=Ar00114&ViewMode=GIF |- | William Thomas "Bill" Brown Jr, 64, male || {{dts|November 11, 1934}}|| Captive|| [[Pecos County, Texas]]|| Brown was killed while trying to recapture a bear from his roadside zoo. A posse shot and killed the bear.{{cite news|title=West Texas Black Bear Kills an East Texas Man Named Brown|url=http://www.texasescapes.com/MikeCoxTexasTales/West-Texas-Black-Bear-Kills-East-Texas-Man.htm|accessdate=31 August 2013|publisher =Texas Tales|date=15 August 2013}} |- | Grant Taylor, 11, male || {{dts|October 2, 1933}}|| Captive ||[[Brookhaven, New York]] ||On his walk home from school, Taylor stopped to feed an apple to a bear [[tether]]ed in front of an inn. The bear mauled Taylor and crushed him against a wire cage. Motorists stopped and used sticks and stones to try to separate the bear from Taylor. Eventually, a man operating a nearby [[roadside stand]] came and shot and killed the bear. An examination revealed that the bear hadn't eaten in two days. The Inn had two bears that were trapped five years previously in the [[Adirondacks]], and were frequently fed by passers-by. Both bears were killed.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LAgtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=X9UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4148,2347830&hl=en|title=Boy, 11, Is Ripped to Pieces As He Tosses Apple to Bear|date=October 3, 1933|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[The Miami News]]|accessdate=27 April 2010}}{{cite news|title=Pet Bear Kills Boy Giving It an Apple|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=3 October 1933}} |- | Peter Matthew Ryan, 5, male || {{dts|October 9, 1932}}|| Captive||[[Albion (town), Orleans County, New York|Albion, New York]] ||Ryan was attacked after trying to get a close look at a pet bear. The bear was tied to a fence at [[Mount Albion Cemetery]] after a truck transporting it broke down.{{cite news|title=Pet Bear Fatally Claws Boy of Five|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1R1JAAAAIBAJ&sjid=PgYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=4769,742870|accessdate=3 June 2013|newspaper=[[The Hour (newspaper)|Norwalk Hour]]|date=11 October 1932}} |- | Emerson Joyce, 60, male || {{dts|June 2, 1930}} ||Captive||[[Watertown, New York]] ||A female black bear who recently had her cubs taken away killed her feeder, Joyce. This occurred at the John C. Thompson Park Zoo.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CqlAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9Q4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=2888,568181&dq=killed+by+a+bear&hl=en|title=Feeder Killed In Bear Cage|date=June 2, 1930|publisher=The Milwaukee Sentinel|accessdate=27 October 2010}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Species ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Charles Wyman, 76, male || {{dts|July 18, 1934}}|| Captive||[[Denver, Colorado]]|| Wyman, a [[zookeeper]], was attacked by two grizzly bears at the [[Denver Zoo]] after spraying them with a water hose. It was speculated that the bears were in a foul mood due to warm weather. The bears were shot.{{cite news|title=Zoo Attendant Killed By Bears|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=jGUhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rIcFAAAAIBAJ|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Reading Eagle]]|date=18 July 1934}} |- | John Macdonald, 70, male || {{dts|October 1932}}||Wild||near [[Dawson, Yukon]]|| Macdonald's mutilated body was initially found in the wilderness {{convert|20|mi|km}} north of Dawson. Macdonald's corpse was moved to a cabin, and before the police arrived, the bear broke into the cabin and scattered the remains.{{cite news|title=Aged Man Killed and Devoured by Grizzly|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ouguAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tdsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4377,3519410|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Ottawa Citizen]]|date=6 October 1932}} Macdonald was a woodcutter who lived alone in a shack on the [[Yukon River]].{{cite news|title=Killed, Eaten by a Grizzly|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eA4_AAAAIBAJ&sjid=S04MAAAAIBAJ&pg=2708,3566427|accessdate=5 April 2011|newspaper=[[Border Cities Star]]|date=1 December 1932}} |- | Thomas Earl, 56, male || {{dts|July 8, 1932}}|| Captive ||[[Cleveland, Ohio]] ||Earl, a zookeeper at the [[Cleveland Metroparks Zoo|Cleveland Brookside Zoo]], was mauled by a brown bear when feeding it in its pen. After a vicious struggle, police shot the bear. Earl was also mistakenly shot, but it was determined that he was already dead.{{cite news|title=Man Torn to Death by Bear in Cleveland Zoo|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1917&dat=19320708&id=ilwhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=bYUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6678,848243|accessdate=18 September 2014|work=Schenectady Gazette|date=Jul 8, 1932}} Earlier in the day, Earl had been fired from his job.{{cite news|title=Loses Zoo Job; Keeper Killed In Bear Cage|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1SpQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BA0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3262,1115773|accessdate=6 April 2011|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=8 July 1932}} |} ==1920s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- |Olga Gregorchuk, <10, female |August 29, 1929 |Wild |near [[Lac Du Bonnet, Manitoba|Lac Du Bonnet, Manitoba]] |Gregorchuk was minding her four-year-old brother, Bill Gregorchuk, while their parents were out working the farm. A large (420 pound) black bear chased Olga and her brother into their family's farm house where it knocked the door in, attacked Olga, dragged her out and ate her. By the time her body was found, it had been consumed with the exception of her head. A small gravestone in Red Deer Cemetery, Manitoba, describes the death. {{Cite book|url=https://scholarworks.umt.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=&httpsredir=1&article=8255&context=etd|title=Of bears and women: Investigating the hypothesis that menstruation attracts bears|last=Byrd|first=Caroline|date=1988-01-01|publisher=University of Montana|language=en}} |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- |Jack Thayer, ?, male |October 16, 1929 |Wild |[[Admiralty Island (Alaska)|Admiralty Island, Alaska]] |Thayer, a U.S. Forest Service employee, and Fred Herring, an assistant, encountered a brown bear at close range while conducting a timber survey on southeast Admiralty Island. Thayer shot the bear while Herring retreated to a tree, but the wounded bear mauled Thayer, who died later that evening.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OorM3SUcEFMC|title=Bear Tales for the Ages: From Alaska and Beyond|last=Kaniut|first=Larry|date=2001-01-01|publisher=Larry Kaniut|isbn=9780970953704|language=en}} |- | Percy Goodair, 52, male || {{dts|September 12, 1929}} || Wild||[[Jasper National Park]], [[Alberta]]||Goodair, a [[Parks Canada]] [[Park ranger|warden]], was killed by a bear while patrolling the [[Tonquin Valley]].{{cite book|last=Burns|first=Robert|title=Guardians of the wild: a history of the warden service of Canada's national parks|year=2000|publisher=University of Calgary Press|isbn=1-55238-018-1|page=189|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gM3pGa9ezJYC&pg=PA189&lpg=PA189}}{{cite web|title=Park Warden Memorial|url=http://www.parkwardens.ca/index.php?id=34|work=National Park Warden Association: Park Warden Memorial |accessdate=10 November 2010}} |- | Joseph B. "Frenchy" Duret, 60, male || {{dts|June 12, 1922}} || Wild ||[[Absaroka-Beartooth Wilderness]], [[Montana]] || Duret was attacked and partially devoured by a huge grizzly. Duret crawled {{convert|1.5|mi|km|adj=on}} back towards his ranch and died in Frenchy Meadow on Slough Creek.{{cite journal|last=Wright |first=Rosalie Muller|title=Grizzly country |journal=[[Sunset (magazine)|Sunset]]|date=October 1, 2000}} |} ==1910s== ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Frank Welch, 61, male || September 8, 1916 || Wild||[[Yellowstone National Park]], [[Wyoming]]|| Welch was killed at a camp near [[Sylvan Pass (Wyoming)|Sylvan Pass]] while carrying a load of hay and oats.{{cite book|last=Whittlesey |first=Lee|title=Death in Yellowstone: Accidents and Foolhardiness in the First National Park|year=1995|publisher=Roberts Rinehart Publishers|isbn=1-57098-021-7|page=39}} Men from the camp killed the bear with a dynamite trap.{{cite web|title=Grizzly Bear Attacks: How wildlife investigators found a killer grizzly in Yellowstone|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/death_in_yellowstone/2012/04/grizzly_bear_attacks_how_wildlife_investigators_found_a_killer_grizzly_in_yellowstone_.single.html|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|accessdate=11 November 2013|last=Grose|first=Jessica}} |} ==1900s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Baby Laird, 1, ? || October 5, 1908 || Captive||[[Tucson, Arizona]] || After a bear escaped from a cage at Elysian Grove Pleasure Park, Buss Laird ran with her infant child in a go-cart. The bear grabbed and killed the baby.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LaUjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BIUFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3862,3342959&dq=killed+by+a+bear&hl=en|title=Bear Killed a Child|date=October 6, 1908|publisher=The Montreal Gazette|accessdate=3 May 2010}} |- | John Dicht, 18, male || November 24, 1906 || Wild ||[[Elk County, Pennsylvania]] ||Thinking the bear was dead, Dicht began skinning it. The bear immediately awoke and tore off one of Dicht's arms, and then killed him.http://digital.olivesoftware.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=WinonaA&BaseHref=TWH/1906/11/26&PageLabelPrint=1&EntityId=Ar00105&ViewMode=GIF |- | Mary Porterfield, 3, female
Wilie Porterfield, 5, male
Henry Porterfield, 7, male || May 19, 1901 || Wild|| [[Job, West Virginia]]|| The children were gathering flowers near their home when they were attacked. A member of a search party found the remains of the children, and shot and killed the bear.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kwZVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_TwNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2794,5448223|title=Three Little Children Killed By Big Bear. Terrible Work Of Wild Beast|date=May 22, 1901|newspaper=[[Paterson Daily Press]]|accessdate=27 October 2010}} |} == 1890s == ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Phillip Henry Vetter, 37, male || September 2, 1892 || Wild|| Near [[Greybull River]], [[Wyoming]]||Vetter, a [[American bison|buffalo]] hunter, had stated to a fellow hunter a week before, that "he would be going out for some bear." A week later, another hunter seeking shelter from rain, investigated his cabin, which had been ransacked by a grizzly bear, and found Vetter dead in the cabin. A newspaper was found which had been written on in blood by Vetter before his death, describing his battle with a grizzly bear, and ending with the words "I'm dying." The hunter, and another man, searched for signs of the bear, and found Vetter's hat, two empty rifle shells, and his rifle with a shell jammed in its chamber. Vetter was buried in [[Old Trail Town]], Cody, Wyoming.{{cite news|title=People in bear country adapt to growing numbers|url=http://trib.com/lifestyles/home-and-garden/people-in-bear-country-adapt-to-growing-numbers/article_f1ad9cb6-532d-576f-a700-f7492bf3dce9.html}} |} ==1880s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Frank Devereaux, 52, male || September 4, 1883 || Wild || [[Cheboygan, Michigan|Cheboygan]], [[Michigan]]||Devereaux and the bear's corpses were found in the woods. There were indications that the bear and man fought each other. Although the article does not mention the species of bear, it is assumed to be a black bear, as this is the only species native to Michigan.{{cite news|title=Condensed Telegrams|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84029385/1883-09-20/ed-1/seq-2/;words=Devereaux|newspaper=Abilene Reflector|date=20 September 1883}}[https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/17389694 Franklin Devereaux at find a grave] |- | John Robinson, ?, male || December 29, 1883 || Wild|| [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]]||Robinson's dead body was found near train tracks. There was evidence of bear tracks and a "terrible struggle".{{cite news|title=Killed By a Bear|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1883/12/30/archives/killed-by-a-bear.html|accessdate=27 October 2010|newspaper=New York Times|date=29 December 1883}} |- | John Dennison, 82, male || June 1881 || Wild||[[Algonquin Provincial Park]], [[Ontario]]|| This was Ontario's first recorded fatal black bear attack. Dennison was inspecting his bear traps on Lake Opeongo, in what is now part of [[Algonquin Park]]. After discovering a bear caught in the trap a struggle between the two ensued, ending in both their deaths.Algonquin Park Archives, Algonquin Park News Letter, Vol. 9, 4 (October 25, 1940), 1. |} ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | "Old Ike," ?, male || June 1886 || Wild || [[Salmon River (Idaho)|Salmon River]], [[Idaho]]|| One of the most successful bear hunters, he killed over 100 grizzlies during the 1800s. In June 1886, he wounded a grizzly bear near the headwaters of the Salmon River, but not enough to cripple the animal. After pursuing it into a dense stand of trees, he was attacked by the bear and mauled, with the bear biting into his chest—crushing his entire chest with one bite. The bear was driven off by his companions.{{cite book|publisher=Lyons Press|last=Brown|first=Gary|title=The Bear Almanac|date=1993|isbn=1558212108|pages=250–251}} |- | Richard Wilson, ?, male || July 1885 || Wild || [[Sedona, Arizona]]|| A bear hunter, Wilson was hunting grizzly bears and shot one near Oak Creek, Arizona. He followed the bear into a thicket and was attacked. He tried to escape by climbing a tree, but the bear pulled him down and killed him. |- | Hyrum Naegle, ?, male || Circa 1885 || Wild || [[Colonia Pacheco]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua, Mexico]]|| Hyrum and his brother shot and wounded a grizzly bear which they pursued, thinking it would soon expire. While brother George was repairing his gun, Hyrum went to shoot the bear but was mauled and killed when the bear crushed his skull. The bear was shot and killed by George's repaired rifle. |} ==1870s== ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | William Waddell, ?, male || 1875 || Wild|| [[Big Basin Redwoods State Park]], [[California]]||Waddell, a [[lumber mill]] owner, was killed near [[Waddell Creek (California)|Waddell Creek]] in [[Santa Cruz County, California|Santa Cruz County]], [[California]].{{cite book|last=Hoover|first=Mildred Brooke |title=Historic spots in California|year=1990|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=0-8047-1734-6|page=433|url=https://books.google.com/?id=p2WrAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA433&lpg=PA433|accessdate=12 July 2010}} |} ==1860s== ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Charles Henry Gates, 35, male || August 30, 1863 || Wild|| [[Cache County, Utah]]||Gates was hunting a grizzly bear that escaped from a trap and was mauled. In 2004, the descendants of Gates placed a new headstone at his [http://news.hjnews.com/news/article_f4dc9d50-70e7-518b-87bc-f19b02855f91.html?mode=jqm gravesite].{{cite news|author=|title=AFFAIRS IN UTAH.; Fatal Adventures with Grizzly Bears--The Peach Crop--Arrival of Saints--Miscellaneous News.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1863/10/03/news/affairs-utah-fatal-adventures-with-grizzly-bears-peach-crop-arrival-saints.html|newspaper=The New York Times|location=New York City, NY|date=October 3, 1863|access-date=May 14, 2015}}{{cite news|last=Riggs|first=Tyler |title=Marking History, Man receives headstone 141 years after death at claws of grizzly bear|year=2004|publisher=The Herald Journal|url=http://news.hjnews.com/news/article_f4dc9d50-70e7-518b-87bc-f19b02855f91.html?mode=jqm}} Retrieved March 8, 2014{{cite web|last=Law|first=Michelle |title=Documents for: Charles Henry Gates|publisher=Family History Database|url=http://lawpioneer.fatcow.com/?controller=individual&action=documents&id=451}} Retrieved March 10, 2014 |} ==1850s== ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Andy Sublette, 46, male || December 19, 1854 || Wild || [[Santa Monica, California]]|| An experienced bear hunter who hunted and killed many bears, Sublette shot and wounded a bear after being separated from his hunting party near present-day Santa Monica in 1854. He was then mauled but stabbed the bear to death with his knife and with the help of his dog. His dog survived, but Sublette died seven days later due to his injuries. |- | Issac Slover, 81, male || October 14, 1854 || Wild || [[Mount San Antonio]]|| A trapper and hunter who hunted grizzly bears even in his older ages, Slover shot and wounded one on Mount San Antonio near his cabin. The large wounded bear crawled into the brush, and Slover reloaded and followed, where he was attacked, torn to pieces, and died. |- | Jim Boggs, ?, male || Circa 1850 || Wild || [[Russian River, California]]|| While hunting grizzly bears, he blundered into the den of a mother with cubs. He was attacked and killed. |} ==1830s== ===Brown bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | Peter Lebec, ?, male || October 17, 1837 || Wild || [[Fort Tejon, California]]|| Lebec was out hunting grizzlies. He dispatched one with a well-placed shot and, assuming it to be dead, approached it. However, the bear rallied and lunged, throwing him to the ground and breaking his neck. He was killed instantly, but the bear was later killed by Native American hunters.Busch, Robert H. (2000). ''The Grizzly Almanac.'' New York, pg. 111. {{ISBN|1-59228-320-9}}. |} ==1780s== ===Black bear=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! style="width:200px;" class="unsortable"|Name, age, gender ! style="width:100px;" class="unsortable"|Date ! class=unsortable|Type ! style="width:150px;" class="unsortable"|Location ! class=unsortable|Description |- | "Son of Mr. Leach," 8, male || August 1784 || Wild ||[[Moultonborough, New Hampshire]]|| The child was sent to a pasture with a horse, and was attacked by a three-year-old bear. Leach, on arrival finding the bear holding his son by the throat, struck the bear with a stake. The bear withdrew, dragging the boy with him. A search was mounted the next day, and the corpse of the boy was discovered, partially devoured. The bear rose from behind a nearby log, and was killed by three gunshots.{{cite book|last=Belknap |first=Jeremy|title=The History of New Hampshire|year=1813|publisher=Bradford and Reed|page=111-112|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wpY-AAAAYAAJ&dq=bear%20attack%20new%20hampshire%201784&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q=bear&f=false}} |} == Maps == {{col-begin|width=auto}} {{col-break}} {{Map of fatal bear attacks in Canada}} {{col-break}} {{Map of fatal bear attacks in the United States}} {{col-break}} {{Map of fatal bear attacks in Alaska}} {{col-end}} == See also == *[[Bear attacks]] *[[Bear danger]] *[[Binky (polar bear)]] *[[Stephen Herrero]] '''Species:''' * [[List of fatal cougar attacks in North America]] * [[List of fatal alligator attacks in the United States]] * [[Coyote attacks on humans]] * [[List of wolf attacks in North America]] * [[Fatal dog attacks in the United States]] ==References== {{reflist|3}} [[Category:Lists of people by cause of death|Fatal bear attacks in North America by decade]] [[Category:North America-related lists|Bears]] [[Category:Deaths due to bear attacks]] [[Category:Deaths due to animal attacks in the United States|*bear]] [[Category:Death-related lists|bear]]

This is a list of people on the [[postage stamp]]s of [[Palau]].
==H== * Captain Henry Wilson (1983), English Captain Henry Wilson shipwrecked the East India Company’s packet, ''Antelope, August 9, 1783 off the coast of Palau''
==J== * [[John James Audubon]] (1985)

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} The '''Maidenhead Locator System''' (a.k.a. '''QTH Locator''' and '''IARU Locator''') is a [[geographic coordinate system|geographic co-ordinate system]] used by [[amateur radio]] operators to succinctly describe their locations, which replaced the deprecated [[QRA locator]] that was limited to European [[Contact (amateur radio)|contact]]s.<ref name="G4FTJ">{{cite book|title=Amateur Radio Operating Manual (third edition)|author=R. J. Eckersley, G4FTJ|publisher=[[Radio Society of Great Britain]]|year=1985|isbn=0-900612-69-X|location=Potters bar, UK|pages=64–66}}</ref> Its purpose is to be concise, accurate and robust in the face of [[Interference (communication)|interference]] and adverse transmission conditions. The Maidenhead Locator System can describe locations anywhere in the world.
Maidenhead locators are also commonly referred to as ''QTH Locator'', ''grid locators'' or ''grid squares'', although the "squares" are distorted on any non-[[equirectangular projection|equirectangular]] [[cartographic projection]]. Use of the terms ''QTH locator'' and ''QRA locator'' was initially discouraged, as it caused confusion with the older QRA locator system. The only abbreviation recommended to indicate a Maidenhead reference in Morse code and radio teleprinter transmission was "LOC", as in "LOC KN28LH".<ref name="G4FTJ"/>
Dr. John Morris [[Amateur_radio#Call_signs|G4ANB]] originally devised the system and it was adopted at a meeting of the VHF Working Group in [[Maidenhead]], England in 1980.<ref name=QRZ.RU-Locator_System/>
==History==
[[DXing|DX]] [[contesting]] is scored based on the distance of [[Contact (amateur radio)|contact]]s, typically 1 point per kilometre,<ref name="SM5AGM-Maidenhead">{{Cite web | title = The Locator System | author = Folke Rosvall, SM5AGM | website = jonit.com | accessdate = 2017-01-30 | url = http://www.jonit.com/fieldlist/maidenhead.htm }}</ref> so there is a need for amateurs to exchange their locations over the air. To facilitate this, following the growth of the sport in the 1950s, the German<ref name=QRZ.RU-Locator_System/> [[QRA locator]] system was adopted in 1959. The QRA locator system was limited to describing European coordinates, however, and by the mid-1970s there was growing recognition for a need for a global locator system.<ref name="SM5AGM-Maidenhead"/>
By the time of their April 1980 meeting, in [[Maidenhead, England]], the VHF Working Group had received 20 different proposals to replace the QRA locator grid. That devised by Dr. John Morris G4ANB was deemed to be the best.<ref name="SM5AGM-Maidenhead"/>
At the 1999 [[International Amateur Radio Union|IARU]] Conference in Lillehammer it was decided that the latitude and longitude to be used as a reference for the determining of locators should be based on the [[World Geodetic System|World Geodetic System 1984]] (WGS-84).<ref name=QRZ.RU-Locator_System>{{cite web |url=http://www.qrz.ru/vhf/qth_h.pdf |title=The Locator System |format=PDF |accessdate=2014-07-13 }}</ref>
==Description of the system== [[Image:Maidenhead Locator System explained.svg|thumb|right]] A Maidenhead locator compresses [[latitude]] and [[longitude]] into a short string of characters, which is similar in concept to the [[World Geographic Reference System]] or GEOREF. This position information is presented in a limited level of precision to limit the number of characters needed for its transmission using voice, [[Morse code]], or any other operating mode.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Edmund Tyson, N5JTY|url-access=subscription|access-date=2018-03-09 |journal=QST |title=Conversion between geodetic and grid locator systems |url=http://www.arrl.org/files/file/protected/Group/Members/Technology/tis/info/pdf/18929.pdf |publisher=The American Radio Relay League |date=January 1989 |location=Newington, CT, |pages=29–30,43 }}</ref>
The chosen coding uses alternating pairs of letters and digits, like so:
* BL11bh16
In each pair, the first character encodes longitude and the second character encodes latitude.<ref>{{cite web |title = Maidenhead Grid Squares |url = http://www.amsat.org/amsat/articles/houston-net/grids.html |author = Bruce Paige, KK5DO |publisher = [[AMSAT]] |year = 2000 |accessdate=10 September 2012 }}</ref> These character pairs also have traditional names, and in the case of letters, the range of characters (or "encoding base number") used in each pair does vary.
[[Image:Maidenhead Locator Map.png|thumb|The world is divided into 324 (18²) Maidenhead fields.]] To avoid negative numbers in the input data, the system specifies that latitude is measured from the [[South Pole]] to the [[North Pole]], and longitude measured eastward from the [[antimeridian]] of [[Greenwich]], giving the [[Prime Meridian]] a [[easting and northing|false easting]] of 180° and the [[equator]] a [[easting and northing|false northing]] of 90°.
To simplify manual encoding, the base for the first pair of letters—traditionally called a ''field''—was chosen to be 18, thus dividing the globe into 18 zones of longitude of 20° each, and 18 zones of latitude 10° each. These zones are encoded with the letters "A" through "R".
[[Image:Maidenhead grid over Europe.svg|thumb|Fields are divided into 100 squares each.]] The second pair of numbers, called a ''square'' and placed after the first pair of letters, uses a base number of 10, and is encoded using the digits "0" to "9". This is where the alternative name "grid squares" comes from. Each of these squares represents 1° of latitude by 2° of longitude. For additional precision, each square can optionally be sub-divided further, into ''subsquares''. These are encoded into a second pair of letters, often (but not always) presented in lowercase. Again, to make manual calculations from degrees and minutes easier, 24 was chosen as the base number, giving these subsquares dimensions of 2.5' of latitude by 5' of longitude. The letters used are "a" through "x".
The resulting Maidenhead subsquare locator string is hence composed of two letters, two digits, and two more letters. To give an example, W1AW, the [[American Radio Relay League]]'s [[Hiram Percy Maxim]] Memorial Station in [[Newington, Connecticut]], is found in grid locator {{Coor Maidenhead|41.71463|-72.72713|yes}}. Two points within the same Maidenhead subsquare are always less than {{cvt|12|km|mi}} apart, which means a Maidenhead locator can give adequate precision from only six easily transmissible characters.
For even more precise location mapping, two additional digits were proposed and ratified as an ''extended locator'', making it altogether eight characters long, and dividing ''subsquares'' into even smaller ones. Such precision has uses in very short communication spans. Beyond this, no common definition exists to extend the system further into even smaller squares. Most often the extending is done by repeating alternating subsquare and square rules (base numbers 24 and 10 respectively). However, other bases for letter encodings have also been observed, and therefore such ''extended extended'' locators might not be compatible.
To summarise: * Character pairs encode [[longitude]] first, and then [[latitude]]. * The first pair (a ''field'') encodes with base 18 and the letters "A" to "R". * The second pair (''square'') encodes with base 10 and the digits "0" to "9". * The third pair (''subsquare'') encodes with base 24 and the letters "a" to "x". * The fourth pair (''extended square'') encodes with base 10 and the digits "0" to "9". * The fifth and subsequent pairs are not formally defined, but recycling the third and fourth pair algorithms is one possible definition: ** BL11bh16oo66
On [[shortwave]] frequencies, positions are reported at ''square'' precision, and on VHF and UHF, ''subsquare'' precision is used. More precise position reports are very rarely used.
==Adoption and use== Like the QRA system before it, Maidenhead locators were enthusiastically adopted by radio amateurs beyond contesting, and it is now in widespread use.
Maidenhead locators are still used as part of the formulas for scoring in many [[VHF]] amateur radio contests and as the basis of earning awards like the American Radio Relay League's [[VHF/UHF Century Club]], URE TTLOC, etc. operating award.
In IARU Region 1 rules, VHF distance calculations are carried out between Maidenhead subsquare centres assuming a ''spherical'' Earth. This results in a small error in distance, but makes calculations simpler and, given the inherent imprecision in the used input data, it is not the biggest error source.
The relatively new [[WSJT_(amateur_radio_software)#FT8|FT8]] narrowband digital mode transmits Maidenhead locator square as part of standard messages, with the 4 character locator square being efficiently represented within 15 bits of the transmitted string.
Until the adoption of [[WGS 84]] as the official [[geodetic datum]] of the Maidenhead locator system in 1999,<ref name=QRZ.RU-Locator_System/> operators had usually specified their location based on their local national datum. Consequently, stations very near the edges of squares (at denoted precision) may have changed their locators when changing over to the use of WGS 84.
==Hardware and software support== In 1985, the Radio Society of Great Britain published a small set of [[BASIC]] language routines to convert from locator references to geographical coordinates (latitude and longitude) for further processing.<ref>{{cite book |author=John Morris, GM4ANB |title=Amateur Radio Software |publisher=Radio Society of Great Britain |year=1985 |isbn=0-900612-71-1 |location=Potters Bar, UK |pages=129–161 }}</ref> A complete program in BASIC called ''Universal Gridlocator'' was made available the following year by ARRL for a nominal cost of US$3.<ref>{{cite journal |journal = QST |author = Wayne Overbeck, N6NB |title = A Universal Grid-Locator Program for Your Personal Computer |date=December 1986 |pages = 30–31 |publisher=[[American Radio Relay League]] |location=Newington, CT }}</ref> Many other utilities exist to convert latitude and longitude to locators, as this is a favourite [[Hack (technology slang)|hack]] for programmers who are also radio amateurs. [[Perl]] supports conversion between geographical coordinates and Maidenhead locators in module Ham::Locator by Andy Smith, available on [[CPAN]].<ref>[http://search.cpan.org/~meh/Ham-Locator-0.1000/lib/Ham/Locator.pm Ham::Locator] CPAN module</ref>
Many commercially available general purpose (civil) [[Global Positioning System]] (GPS) receivers (e.g. Garmin GPS-12) have the option to display positions in Maidenhead Locator format.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.n7cfo.com/vhf/gps/~gps.htm |author=L.A. Burlingame, N7CFO |title=GPS Units That Support the Maidenhead Grid System |accessdate=9 September 2012 |year=2010 }}</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Manuel María Paz Delgado | image = Manuel Maria Paz.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1820|06|06}} | birth_place = [[Almaguer]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1902|09|16|1820|06|06}} | death_place = [[Bogotá]] | nationality = {{COL}} | other_names = | occupation = Cartographer, military officer, artist and painter | years_active = 1832-1895 | organization = Comisión Corográfica | known_for = | spouse = Felisa Castro | children = José Domingo, Felisa, Francisco, María, Ana María, Julián | parents = Domingo de Paz, Baltazara Delgado | relatives = José Miguel de Paz, Carmen de Paz }}
'''Manuel María Paz Delgado''' (July 6, 1820, [[Almaguer, Cauca]], [[Colombia]] - Sept. 16, 1902 [[Bogotá]]) was a Colombian cartographer, military officer, artist and watercolorist.<ref name="Recuento">{{cite web |url=http://www.colarte.com/recuentos/P/PazManuelMaria/recuento.htm |title =Manuel María Paz | accessdate = 3 Sep 2011 | author = Carmen Ortega Ricaurte | date =|language = Spanish }}</ref><ref name="Obra">{{cite web | url = http://www.rtspecialties.com/tobar/conex1/ostogo/mmpaz.htm | title = La obra pictórica de Manuel María Paz y la Comisión Corográfica | accessdate = 3 Sep 2011 | last = Tobar Gómez | first = Oscar | date = | language = Spanish }}</ref>
== Biography ==
Manuel María Paz Delgado was born June 6, 1820 in the town of [[Almaguer, Cauca]], [[Colombia]]. His parents were Domingo de Paz and Baltazara Delgado, and his siblings were José Miguel de Paz and Carmen de Paz.<ref name="Obra"/> After studying literature in his native Amaguer and still being quite young, he moved to [[Popayán]] to serve as a soldier in the Guardia Nacional, joining Dec. 29, 1839.<ref name="Obra"/>
As a private he participated in several of the civil wars of the [[Republic of New Granada]], and distinguished himself for his bravery.<ref name="Recuento"/><ref name="Obra"/> As the years passed, he rose through the military ranks, obtaining the rank of [[Colonel]] in 1848.<ref name="Recuento"/> At the same time, along with his military career, he was also developing a career as a painter and cartographer, participating in an 1848 artistic exhibition with the "Mesa Revuelta",<ref name="Obra"/> a work highly admired by the exhibition's selection jury.
[[File:Manuel María Paz (watercolor 9098, 1855 CE).jpg|thumb|Watercolor of the [[Lagunas de Siecha]], in [[Chingaza Natural National Park]], painted by Manuel María Paz in 1855 during the Comisión Corográfica.]]
In 1852 he was married to Felisa Castro. Six children resulted from this union, José Domingo, Felisa, Francisco, María, Ana María y Julián.<ref name="Obra"/> In 1853 he joined the [[Comisión Corográfica]] to work as an artist with [[Henry Price (painter)|Henry Price]], who later retired from the project for reasons of health.<ref name="Recuento"/>
Between 1853 and 1858 he painted 127 lithogaphed watercolors,<ref name="Recuento"/><ref>52 lithogaphed watercolors in 1853 during the fourth corográfic expedition, 16 in 1855 during the sixth expedition, 11 in 1856 during the seventh expedition, 16 in 1857 during the eighth expedition, and more than 32 illustrations of the [[San Agustín culture]], executed by [[Agustín Codazzi]].</ref> which not only served to illustrate the work of the Comisión, but also included other works published separately under the auspices of [[Agustín Codazzi]]. During these years, María Paz also assisted the celebrated geographer in creating maps of the different regions of the country.
Codazzi died in 1859, in the arms of his friend Manuel María Paz.<ref name="Obra"/> As a result, the work of the Comisión came to a complete stop. [[Tomás Cipriano de Mosquera]] did not want the work to be lost, so he contracted with María Paz and Manuel Ponce de León to finish the works begun under the direction of General Codazzi, and to publish them.<ref name="Obra"/> As a result of this effort, the ''Atlas de los Estados Unidos de Colombia'' appeared in 1865, followed by the ''Atlas Geográfico e Histórico de la República de Colombia'' in 1889. The French [[Société de géographie]] conferred membership on Paz on Dec. 6, 1889 based on the second of the two publications.<ref name="Obra"/>
In the period between the publication of the two works, he also participated in various artistic expositions, such as an 1871 exhibition commemorating celebrating the ''fiestas patrias'' (patriotic national holidays), and in 1883, as a part of the celebrations commemorating the birth of Simón Bolívar the liberator.<ref name="Recuento"/>
After an exhausting but productive life, Manual María Paz Delgado died on Sept. 16, 1902, in the parish of [[San Victorino]] in [[Bogotá]].<ref name="Recuento"/>
== Publications ==
* ''[[:m:commons:Agustin Codazzi Atlas de los Estados Unidos de Colombia 1865|Atlas de los Estados Unidos de Colombia]]'' (1865). Edited with [[Manuel Ponce de León]]. * ''[[:m:commons:Agustin Codazzi Atlas de Colombia 1890|Atlas Geográfico e Histórico de la República de Colombia]]'' (1889). Edited with [[Felipe Pérez]]. * ''Carta del territorio de los chibchas'' (1894). * ''Diccionario Geográfico Estadístico Histórico de la Nueva Granada''. * ''Itinerario general de las distancias que existen en la capital de los Estados Unidos de Colombia a las diferentes poblaciones de cada uno de los estados'' (1870). * ''Láminas de la Comisión Corográfica'' (1853-1858). * ''Mapa Económico de la República de Colombia''. * ''Mapa General de Colombia y los particulares de los Estados'' (1873). * ''Primer Itinerario de Distancias de la República de Colombia''. * ''Libreta de apuntes'' (2011) Facsimile edition of the pamphlet. Contains drawings and sketches drawn during the seventh and eight expeditions of the Comisión Corográfica. Published by the Universidad de Caldas and the Universidad EAFIT.
== Paintings == * Paintings by Manuel María Paz Delgado from the Comisión Corográfica are held in the collections of the [[National Library of Colombia]], and accessible online.<ref>{{Cite web | title = Works by Manuel María Paz (1820–1902) | work = World Digital Library | accessdate = 2014-05-24 | url = http://www.wdl.org/en/search/?q=Manuel+Mar%C3%ADa+Paz&qla=en }}</ref>
